Prompt: where was the world economic forum held this year
Ground truth: The forum is best known for its annual meeting at the end of January in Davos, a mountain resort in Graubünden, in the eastern Alps region of Switzerland. The meeting brings together some 2,500 top business leaders, international political leaders, economists, celebrities and journalists for up to four days to discuss the most pressing issues facing the world. Often this location alone is used to identify meetings, participation, and participants, with such phrases as "a Davos panel" and "Davos man" being used.

Prompt: who was the first chief minister of west bengal
Ground truth: Since 1947, there have been eight Chief Ministers of West Bengal. The first was Prafulla Chandra Ghosh of the Indian National Congress, who was succeeded by his party-mates Dr Bidhan Chandra Roy and Prafulla Chandra Sen. A decade of instability followed, marred by fractious coalition governments and frequent impositions of President's rule. The instability ended with 1977 election victory of the Communist Party of India (Marxist) (CPM). Headed by Jyoti Basu, the CPM-led Left Front government was in office for over 23 years (1977--2000). Left rule in West Bengal continued for another 10 years under Buddhadeb Bhattacharya, before its defeat in the 2011 election by the Trinamool Congress. Appointed on 20 May 2011, Trinamool leader Mamata Banerjee is the current incumbent, the state's first woman chief minister.
[0.000, 0.154, 0.085, 0.112, 0.552] Agent refined response: Prafulla Chandra Ghosh was the first Chief Minister of West Bengal.
[0.000, 0.154, 0.099, 0.112, 0.560] Ori response: the first chief minister of West Bengal was Prafulla Chandra Ghosh.

The Capitol, a highly advanced metropolis, exercises political control over the rest of the nation. The Hunger Games is an annual event in which one boy and one girl aged 12--18 from each of the twelve districts surrounding the Capitol are selected by lottery to compete in a televised battle to the death.

Prompt: what is the maximum data rate for the 802.11a standard select one
Ground truth: The 802.11 a standard uses the same data link layer protocol and frame format as the original standard, but an OFDM based air interface (physical layer). It operates in the 5 GHz band with a maximum net data rate of 54 Mbit/s, plus error correction code, which yields realistic net achievable throughput in the mid-20 Mbit/s.
[0.183, 0.396, 0.149, 0.271, 0.648] Agent refined response: 802.11 a standard provides protocols that allow transmission and receipt of data at rates of 1,5 to 54 mbit/s. Therefore, the maximum data rate for the 111.11a standard is 54 mbit/s

Prompt: who is recognized as the founder of islam
Ground truth: According to tradition, the Islamic prophet Muhammad was born in Mecca around the year 570. His family belonged to the Quraysh. When he was about forty years old, he began receiving what Muslims consider to be divine revelations delivered through the angel Gabriel, which would later form the Quran, enjoining him to proclaim a strict monotheistic faith, warn his compatriots of the impending Judgement Day, and castigate social injustices of his city. Muhammad's message won over a handful of followers and was met with increasing opposition from notables of Mecca. In 618, after he lost protection with the death of his influential uncle Abu Talib, Muhammad took flight to the city of Yathrib (subsequently called Medina) where he was joined by his followers. Later generations would count this event, known as the hijra, as the start of the Islamic era.
[0.000, 0.078, 0.013, 0.078, 0.474] Agent refined response: Muhammad (peace be upon him) is recognized as the founder of Islam.
[0.000, 0.054, 0.014, 0.054, 0.481] Ori response: Muhammad is recognized as the founder of Islam.

Prompt: where does the term dog and pony show come from
Ground truth: The term was originally used in the United States in the late-19th and early-20th centuries to refer to small traveling circuses that toured through small towns and rural areas. The name derives from the common use of performing dogs and ponies as the main attractions of the events. Performances were generally held in open-air arenas, such as race tracks or public spaces in localities that were too small or remote to attract larger, more elaborate performers or performances. The most notorious was "Prof. Gentry's Famous Dog & Pony Show," started when teenager Henry Gentry and his brothers started touring in 1886 with their act, originally entitled "Gentry's Equine and Canine Paradox." It started small, but evolved into a full circus show. Other early dog and pony shows included Morris' Equine and Canine Paradoxes (1883) and Hurlburt's Dog and Pony Show (late 1880s).
[0.233, 0.371, 0.139, 0.198, 0.603] Agent refined response: the term "dog and pony show" is a slang term that originated in the United States. It is believed to have been used in the early 20th century and was likely derived from the idea of a traveling medicine show or carnival act that featured a "dog and pony" act as a way to attract an audience. Over time, the term came to be used more broadly to refer to any kind of entertainment or spectacle that is considered to be overly elaborate or excessive.
[0.237, 0.409, 0.149, 0.209, 0.615] Ori response: the term "dog and pony show" is a slang term that originated in the United States. It is believed to have been used in the early 20th century, and was likely derived from the idea of a traveling medicine show or carnival act that featured a dog and a pony as the main attractions. Over time, the term evolved to be used more broadly to refer to any type of entertainment or performance that is perceived as being trivial or lacking in substance.

Prompt: what do the 3 dots mean in math
Ground truth: In logical argument and mathematical proof, the therefore sign (∴) is generally used before a logical consequence, such as the conclusion of a syllogism. The symbol consists of three dots placed in an upright triangle and is read therefore. It is encoded at U + 2234 ∴ therefore (HTML & # 8756; &there4;). For common use in Microsoft Office hold the ALT key and type "8756". While it is not generally used in formal writing, it is used in mathematics and shorthand. It is complementary to U + 2235 ∵ because (HTML & # 8757;).
[0.317, 0.351, 0.067, 0.190, 0.559] Agent refined response: 3 dots in a triangle shape are used to signify "therefore" in the 18th century. However, the origin of this notation is not clear, and it became less common in continental Europe in the 19th century. However, it remains popular in the British Isles.

In math, the 3 dots are commonly used to indicate a conclusion or a logical consequence. For example, in a syllogism, the 3 dots can be used to represent the conclusion that follows from the premises.

Here is an example of how the 3 dots can be use in a syllogism:

All gods are immortal.
Zeus is a god.
Therefore, Zeus is immortal.


In this example, the 3 dots are used to represent the conclusion that follows logically from the premises.
[0.260, 0.298, 0.053, 0.175, 0.561] Ori response: 3 dots in a triangle shape, also known as "therefore," were used by authors in the 18th century to signify "therefore." However, there wasn't much consistency in how the triangle was oriented.

In the 19th century, the three-dot notation for "therefore" became more common, but it remained rare in continental Europe. However, it remains popular in the British Isles.

In math, the three dots are often used to indicate a conclusion or a logical implication. For example, in a syllogism, the three dots can be used to represent the conclusion that follows from the premises.

Here's an example of how the three dots might be used in a syllogism:

All gods are immortal.
Zeus is a god.
Therefore, Zeus is immortal.

In this example, the three dots are used to indicate the logical implication that follows from the premises.

Ground truth: In the National Football League, training camp refers to the time before the season commences. During this time, teams will sometimes congregate at an outside location, usually a university, to conduct training camp for at least the first few weeks. This is similar to baseball's spring training.
[0.347, 0.339, 0.073, 0.179, 0.572] Agent refined response: NFL training camp for players typically lasts for several weeks, with the exact duration varying from team to team. The training camp usually starts in late July and can last anywhere from 3 to 4 weeks, with some teams holding longer camps. However, the second half of training camp, which leads directly into the exhibition season, is considered more important than the first half.
[0.261, 0.266, 0.048, 0.172, 0.523] Ori response: NFL training camp typically lasts for 4-5 weeks, with the exact duration varying depending on the team and the player's position. The first half of training camp, which lasts for 2-3 weeks, is focused on conditioning and individual drills, while the second half, which lasts for 2 weeks, is more focused on team drills and scrimmages. The training camp schedule usually starts in late July and ends in late August, with the exhibition season beginning shortly after.

Prompt: where does the movie proof of life take place
Ground truth: The Republic of Tecala, where most of Proof of Life is set, is a fictional South American country. Tecala has long been the scene of an internal conflict between its government forces and the Liberation Army of Tecala (ELT). The ELT was originally a Marxist guerrilla group supported by the Soviet Union, but after the Soviet Union's dissolution in 1991, the ELT's primary source of funding fell through, and they began kidnapping people for ransom to fund their operations. A map seen in the film is that of Ecuador. The country's capital Quito was chosen along with the eastern jungle and the nearby city of Baños de Agua Santa in the Ecuadorian Andes.

Ex-England football team captain Gary Lineker and ex-England cricket team captain David Gower were team captains from 1995 until they announced their retirement from the show in 2003. From October 2005, Boris Becker replaced Tufnell and Lee Mack took over from Hancock as host.

Prompt: how many cracker barrels in the united states
Ground truth: The number of combined restaurants and stores owned by Cracker Barrel increased between 1997 and 2000, to more than 420 locations. In 2000 and 2001, the company addressed staffing and infrastructure issues related to this rapid growth by implementing a more rigorous recruitment strategy and introducing new technology, including an order-placement system. From the late 1990s to the mid-2000s, the company focused on opening new locations in residential areas to attract local residents and workers as customers. It updated its marketing in 2006 to encourage new customers, changing the design of its highway billboard advertisements to include images of menu items. Previously the signs had featured only the company's logo. By 2011, Cracker Barrel had opened more than 600 restaurants in 42 states. On January 17, 2012, company founder Dan Evins died of bladder cancer.

Prompt: first jnanpith award was an autor of which language
Ground truth: G. Sankara Kurup, (3 June 1901, Nayathode, Kingdom of Cochin (now in Ernakulam district, Kerala, India)--2 February 1978, Vappalassery, Angamaly, Ernakulam district, Kerala), better known as Mahakavi G (The Great Poet G), was the first winner of the Jnanpith Award, India's highest literary award. He won the prize in 1965 for his collection of poems in Malayalam Odakkuzhal (The Bamboo Flute, 1950). With part of the prize money he established the literary award Odakkuzhal in 1968. He was also the recipient of the Soviet Land Nehru Award, in 1967, and the Padma Bhushan in 1968. His poetry collection Viswadarshanam won the Kerala Sahitya Akademi Award in 1961 and Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award in 1963.
[0.006, 0.173, 0.044, 0.144, 0.535] Agent refined response: G. Shankara Kurup is the author of Malayalam literature. Therefore, the first Jnanpith Award was given to an author of the Malayalam language.
[0.110, 0.426, 0.301, 0.387, 0.697] Ori response: G. Shankara Kurup was the first recipient of the Jnanpith Award, which is India's highest literary award. He won the award in 1965 forhis collection of poems in Malayalam, "Odakkuzhal" (The Bamboo Flute), which he published in 1950.

Prompt: where does us highway 1 start and end
Ground truth: U.S. Route 1 (US 1) is a major north--south U.S. Highway that serves the East Coast of the United States. It runs 2,369 miles (3,813 km), from Fort Kent, Maine, at the Canada--US border, south to Key West, Florida, making it the longest north--south road in the United States. US 1 is generally paralleled by Interstate 95 (I-95), though the former is significantly farther west (inland) between Jacksonville, Florida, and Petersburg, Virginia. The highway connects most of the major cities of the East Coast--including Miami, Jacksonville, Richmond, Washington, D.C., Baltimore, Philadelphia, New York City and Boston, passing from the Southeastern United States to New England.
[0.349, 0.370, 0.058, 0.173, 0.572] Agent refined response: US Highway 1 starts and ends as follows:

* Starts: York City, Pennsylvania
* Ends: Boston, Massachusetts



In more detail, US Highway 1 passes through the following cities and states:

* From York City, Pennsylvania, it heads northeast through Maryland, Delaware, and New Jersey, passing through the Delaware Bay and the Atlantic coast.
* In Massachusetts, it passes through the Boston metropolitan area before terminating in Boston.


It's worth noting that while US Highway 1 is generally the easternmost main north-south highway in the United States, parts of it run east of US Highway 1 in some cases. For example, US Highway 13 terminates only a few miles west of US Highway  1 in Falls Township, Pennsylvania, with over 99.5% of its route running east of US Highway 1.

Prompt: who breaks a tie in the us senate
Ground truth: The Vice President of the United States is the ex officio President of the Senate, as provided in Article I, Section 3, Clause 4, of the United States Constitution, but may only vote in order to break a tie. According to the U.S. Senate, as of February 28, 2018, a tie-breaking vote had been cast 264 times by 36 vice presidents.
[0.598, 0.681, 0.441, 0.551, 0.781] Agent refined response: the Vice President of the United States breaks a tie in the US Senate. This means that when there is a tie vote in the Senate, the Vice President is called upon to cast a tie-breaking vote to resolve the deadlock. This is provided for in Article I, Section 3, Clause 4 of the US Constitution. As of February 28, 2023, a tie-breaking vote had been cast 266 times by 36 Vice Presidents.
[0.512, 0.567, 0.288, 0.328, 0.677] Ori response: the Vice President of the United States breaks a tie in the US Senate. In the event of a tie, the Vice President is called upon to cast a tie-breaking vote. This power is granted to the Vice President under Article I, Section 3 of the United States Constitution, which states that the Vice President shall "preside over the Senate, but shall have no vote, unless they be equally divided."

Prompt: who is the founder of google and when was it founded
Ground truth: Google Inc. is an American multinational technology company that specializes in Internet-related services and products. These include online advertising technologies, search, cloud computing, software, and hardware. Google was founded in 1998 by Larry Page and Sergey Brin while they were Ph. D. students at Stanford University, in California. Together, they own about 14 percent of its shares, and control 56 percent of the stockholder voting power through supervoting stock. They incorporated Google as a privately held company on September 4, 1998. An initial public offering (IPO) took place on August 19, 2004, and Google moved to its new headquarters in Mountain View, California, nicknamed the Googleplex. In August 2015, Google announced plans to reorganize its various interests as a conglomerate called Alphabet Inc. Google, Alphabet's leading subsidiary, will continue to be the umbrella company for Alphabet's Internet interests. Upon completion of the restructure, Sundar Pichai was appointed CEO of Google; he replaced Larry Page, who became CEO of Alphabet.

Prompt: what does it mean to be on parole
Ground truth: Parole is a temporary release of a prisoner who agrees to certain conditions before the completion of the maximum sentence period, originating from the French parole ("voice, spoken words"). The term became associated during the Middle Ages with the release of prisoners who gave their word.
[0.115, 0.172, 0.025, 0.123, 0.493] Agent refined response: "parole is an option for most prisoners." This means that after serving a certain portion of their sentence, prisoners may be eligible to be released on parole, which is supervision provided by a parole board. Parole allows individuals to serve the remainder of their sentence in the community rather than in prison, under the supervision of a parole officer.

During the parole process, the parole board will assess the individual's progress in their rehabilitation and reintegration into society. If the individual has made sufficient progress and has demonstrated that they are no longer a danger to society, the parole board may grant parole. However, parole is not guaranteed, and the parole board may deny parole if the individual has not made sufficient progress or if they are deemed to be a danger to society.

It is important to note that the specific eligibility requirements and parole process vary depending on the jurisdiction and the type of offense committed. For example, in some jurisdictions, individuals convicted of first-degree murder may be eligible for parole after 25 or 30 years, while individuals convicted of less serious offenses may be eligible for paroles after a shorter period of time.
[0.296, 0.325, 0.052, 0.205, 0.536] Ori response: "parole is an option for most prisoners." This means that after serving a certain portion of their sentence, prisoners may be eligible for parole, which is a type of early release from prison. However, it is important to note that parole is not guaranteed, particularly in cases of life or indeterminate sentences, and the length of parole eligibility can vary depending on the circumstances of the offense and the individual case.

Prompt: the origins of the stations of the cross
Ground truth: The Stations of the Cross or the Way of the Cross, also known as the Way of Sorrows or the Via Crucis, refers to a series of images depicting Jesus Christ on the day of his crucifixion and accompanying prayers. The stations grew out of imitations of Via Dolorosa in Jerusalem which is believed to be the actual path Jesus walked to Mount Calvary. The object of the stations is to help the Christians faithful to make a spiritual pilgrimage through contemplation of the Passion of Christ. It has become one of the most popular devotions and the stations can be found in many Western Christian churches, including Anglican, Lutheran, Methodist, and Roman Catholic ones.
[0.276, 0.304, 0.047, 0.210, 0.483] Agent refined response: 14 traditional stations of the cross have been established, which are as follows:

1. Jesus is condemned to death
2. Jesus is led to the place of crucifixion
3. Jesus falls for the first time
4. Jesus meets his mother
5. Simon of Cyrene is compelled to carry the cross
6. Jesus falls for the second time
7. Jesus is nailed to the cross
8. Jesus dies on the cross
9. Jesus is taken down from the cross
10. Jesus is placed in the tomb
11. Jesus is found in the tomb
12. Jesus is carried to his burial site
13. Jesus rises from the dead
14. Jesus appears to his disciples

However, it is important to note that not all of these stations have clear scriptural foundations, with stations 3, 4, and 6 being among those without any explicit biblical basis.
[0.311, 0.377, 0.088, 0.202, 0.543] Ori response: 14 traditional stations of the cross have been established, with only 8 of them having clear scriptural foundations. The other 6 stations (3, 4, 6 7, and 9) are not specifically attested to in the Bible.

The origins of the stations of the Cross can be traced back to the early Christian Church, particularly in the Eastern Orthodox Church and the Roman Catholic Church. The stations were originally developed as a way for pilgrims to follow the path of Jesus Christ's suffering and death, as well as his resurrection.

The 14 traditional stations of the Cross were codified in the 12th century by the Catholic Church, with the first station being the condemnation of Jesus by Pontius Pilate, and the last station being the resurrection of Jesus. These stations are as follows:

1. Condemnation of Jesus by Pontius Pontius Pilate
2. Jesus is made to carry his cross
3. Jesus falls for the first time
4. Jesus meets his mother, Mary
5. Simon of Cyrene is compelled to carry the cross
6. Jesus falls for the second time
7. Jesus speak

Prompt: when did beryl markham fly across the atlantic
Ground truth: When Markham decided to take on the Atlantic crossing, no female pilot had yet flown non-stop from Europe to New York, and no woman had made the westward flight solo, though several had died trying. Markham hoped to claim both records. On 4 September 1936, she took off from Abingdon, England. After a 20-hour flight, her Vega Gull, The Messenger, suffered fuel starvation due to icing of the fuel tank vents, and she crash-landed at Baleine Cove on Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia, Canada. She became the first person to make it from England to North America non-stop from east to west. She was celebrated as an aviation pioneer.
[0.000, 0.141, 0.079, 0.109, 0.520] Agent refined response: Beryl Markham successfully flew across the Atlantic from east to west non-stop in 1930.
[0.002, 0.197, 0.092, 0.136, 0.549] Ori response: Beryl Markham became the first woman to successfully fly across Atlantic from east to west non-stop in 1930.

He threw his son out of the house when John Jr. decided to work at the 15th with Andy; his partner and he later worked a case with Clark Jr. and Andy that revealed Clark Sr.'s by-the-book approach and hyper-sensitivity to his son being anything like Andy. (In fact, Andy was much more the kind of detective Clark Jr. wanted to be, which is why he chose to transfer to the 15th when he earned a detective's shield and pick of assignments.) Clark Sr. later got busted for sleeping with a prostitute and let his son face the IAB accusation and potential discipline until Andy told him Clark Jr. was on the verge of being fired, which caused Clark Sr. to confess. After this, Clark Sr. began drinking heavily and became an IAB informant, which nearly ruined John's career at the 15th. His actions helped lead to the campaign by Officer Laughlin against Clark Jr., who finally told his father to stop making bad decisions on his behalf and stop drinking so much. A depressed Clark Sr. later committed suicide, which sent his son into a long depression of his own. Played by Joe Spano.

Prompt: what does the sun represent on the uruguay flag
Ground truth: The horizontal stripes on the flag represent the nine original departments of Uruguay, based on the U.S flag, where the stripes represent the original 13 colonies. The first flag designed in 1828 had 9 light blue stripes; this number was reduced to 4 in 1830 due to visibility problems from distance. The Sun of May represents the May Revolution of 1810; according to the historian Diego Abad de Santillán, the Sun of May is a figurative sun that represents Inti, the sun god of the Inca religion. It also appears in the Flag of Argentina and the Coat of Arms of Bolivia.
[0.292, 0.523, 0.344, 0.458, 0.707] Agent refined response: the sun on the Uruguay flag represents the May Revolution of 1810, specifically the "Sun of May" or "Sol de Mayo" in Spanish. This is a figurative sun that represents Inti, the sun god of the Inca religion, and is also featured on the flags of Argentina and Bolivia.
[0.220, 0.456, 0.245, 0.389, 0.696] Ori response: the sun on the Uruguay flag represents the May Revolution of 1810, which was led by José Gervasio Artigas. The sun is also a symbol of Inti, the sun god of the Inca religion, and appears on the flags of Argentina and Bolivia as well.

Prompt: when does a limit of a function not exist
Ground truth: Formal definitions, first devised in the early 19th century, are given below. Informally, a function f assigns an output f (x) to every input x. We say the function has a limit L at an input p: this means f (x) gets closer and closer to L as x moves closer and closer to p. More specifically, when f is applied to any input sufficiently close to p, the output value is forced arbitrarily close to L. On the other hand, if some inputs very close to p are taken to outputs that stay a fixed distance apart, we say the limit does not exist.
[0.251, 0.271, 0.070, 0.140, 0.505] Agent refined response: a limit of a function does not exist in the following cases:



1. As special cases, limits on an interval have no value.
2. Left-hand limits of real-valued functions, such as taking $s$ to be an open interval of the format $(-\infty,a)$ or $(a,\infty)$.
3. Right-hand limits of real-valuED functions, such as taking $s$$ to be an open interval of theformat $(a, \infty)$ or $(-\infty,a)$.
4. The notion of one-sided limits is extended to the included endpoints of half-closed intervals, so the square root function $f(x) = \sqrt{x}$ can have limit $0$ as $x$ approaches $0$ from above.

In summary, a limit of a function does no exist in any of these special cases.
[0.273, 0.261, 0.076, 0.168, 0.554] Ori response: a limit of a function does not exist in the following cases:

1. As special cases, limits on an interval have no real value. For example, the limit of f(x) as x approaches 0 from the left does not exist.
2. Left-hand limits of real-valued functions. For instance, the limit of f(x)=√x as x approaches (−∞,a) does not exist.
3. Right-hand limits of real-valuED functions. For example, the limit of  f(x)=√x as  x approaches (a,∞) does not exist.
4. One-sided limits at the included endpoints of half-closed intervals. For instance, the limit of  f(n) as n approaches 0 from the right does not exist.

These are the scenarios where a limit of a function does not have a well-defined value.
================================================================================
Prompt: when did under the cork tree come out
Ground truth: From Under the Cork Tree is the second studio album by American rock band Fall Out Boy. It was released on May 3, 2005, through Island Records as the band's major label debut. The music was composed by lead vocalist and guitarist Patrick Stump, with all lyrics penned by bassist Pete Wentz, continuing the band's songwriting approach they took for some songs on their prior 2003 effort Take This to Your Grave. Neal Avron handled production duties. Commenting on the record's lyrical themes, Wentz said the lyrics were about "the anxiety and depression that goes along with looking at your own life." In support of their release the group headlined tours worldwide and played at various music festivals. For their Black Clouds and Underdogs tour the album was re-released as From Under the Cork Tree (Limited "Black Clouds and Underdogs" Edition), featuring new songs and remixes.
[0.000, 0.124, 0.101, 0.124, 0.483] Agent refined response: "From Under the Cork Tree" was released on May 3, 2006.
[0.000, 0.170, 0.123, 0.170, 0.491] Ori response: "From Under the Cork Tree" by Fall Out Boy was released on May 3, 2006.
================================================================================
Prompt: where does eye of the round roast come from
Ground truth: A round steak is a beef steak from the "round", the rear leg of the cow. The round is divided into cuts including the eye (of) round, bottom round, and top round, with or without the "round" bone (femur), and may include the knuckle (sirloin tip), depending on how the round is separated from the loin. This is a lean cut and it is moderately tough. Lack of fat and marbling makes round dry out when cooked with dry-heat cooking methods like roasting or grilling. Round steak is commonly prepared with slow moist-heat methods including braising, to tenderize the meat and maintain moisture. The cut is often sliced thin, then dried or smoked at low temperature to make jerky.

2. Permian Basin: Located in western Texas and southeastern New Mexico, the Permian Basin is the second-largest natural gas-producing region in  the United States. The Permian Basin is known for its rich gas reserves and has seen significant growth in recent years due to advances in hydraulic fracturing (fracking) technology.

Prompt: who gave the famous objective co relative theory
Ground truth: The theory of the objective correlative as it relates to literature was largely developed through the writings of the poet and literary critic T.S. Eliot, who is associated with the literary group called the New Critics. Helping define the objective correlative, Eliot's essay "Hamlet and His Problems", republished in his book The Sacred Wood: Essays on Poetry and Criticism discusses his view of Shakespeare's incomplete development of Hamlet's emotions in the play Hamlet. Eliot uses Lady Macbeth's state of mind as an example of the successful objective correlative: "The artistic ' inevitability ' lies in this complete adequacy of the external to the emotion.", as a contrast to Hamlet. According to Eliot, the feelings of Hamlet are not sufficiently supported by the story and the other characters surrounding him. The objective correlative's purpose is to express the character's emotions by showing rather than describing feelings as discussed earlier by Plato and referred to by Peter Barry in his book Beginning Theory: An Introduction to Literary and Cultural Theory as ". perhaps little more than the ancient distinction (first made by Plato) between mimesis and diegesis." (28). According to Formalist critics, this action of creating an emotion through external factors and evidence linked together and thus forming an objective correlative should produce an author's detachment from the depicted character and unite the emotion of the literary work. The "occasion" of E. Montale is a further form of correlative.
[0.021, 0.254, 0.128, 0.181, 0.578] Agent refined response: T.S. Eliot is largely associated with the development of the theory of the objective correlative in literature. He is a poet and literary critic who is credited with advancing the idea that an objective correlative is a literary device used to provide explicit, rather than implicit, accessibility to traditionally inexplicable ideas such as emotion or color.
[0.015, 0.253, 0.117, 0.177, 0.580] Ori response: T.S. Eliot is largely associated with the development of the theory of the objective correlative in literature. Eliot, a poet and literary critic, wrote extensively on the concept of the objective correlative and its role in literature. He is credited with popularizing the term and its application in literary analysis.

Prompt: who won the champions league final in 2016
Ground truth: The 2016 UEFA Champions League Final was the final match of the 2015--16 UEFA Champions League, the 61st season of Europe's premier club football tournament organised by UEFA, and the 24th season since it was renamed from the European Champion Clubs' Cup to the UEFA Champions League. It was played at the San Siro stadium in Milan, Italy, on 28 May 2016, between Spanish teams Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid, in a repeat of the 2014 final. It was the second time in the tournament's history that both finalists were from the same city. Real Madrid won 5--3 on a penalty shoot-out after a 1--1 draw at the end of extra time, securing a record-extending 11th title in the competition.

Becker wrote that most Americans had absorbed Locke's works as a kind political gospel, and the Declaration, in its form and phraseology, follows closely certain sentences from Locke's Second Treatise on Government. Prompt: when does canada switch to daylight savings time
Ground truth: In regions where daylight saving time is used, it commences on the second Sunday of March, and standard time restarts on the first Sunday in November.
[0.086, 0.196, 0.085, 0.140, 0.531] Agent refined response: Canada observes Daylight Saving Time (DST) in all ten Canadian provinces and three territories. However, there are exceptions within several provinces, including most of Saskatchewan, which observers Central Standard Time year-round, even though the province is in the Mountain zone, effectively putting it on DST year-round.

In Canada, the start and end dates of DST vary depending on the province or territory. Here are the approximate start and end dates of DST in each province and territory:

* British Columbia: Second Sunday in March to first Sunday in November
* Nunavut: Second Sunday in March to first Monday in September
* Ontario: First Sunday in March to last Sunday in October
* Quebec: First Sunday in April to last Sunday in October
* Saskatchewan: Uniform Time Act does not apply, but generally follows Central Standard Time year-round

It is important to note that these dates are subject to change, and the exact start and end dates may vary depending on the specific province or territory. It is always best to check the official government website or a reliable source for the most up-to-date information on DST in Canada.
[0.086, 0.209, 0.074, 0.147, 0.525] Ori response: Canada observes Daylight Saving Time (DST) in all ten Canadian provinces and three territories. However, there are exceptions within several provinces, including most of Saskatchewan, which observers Central Standard Time year-round, even though the province is in the Mountain zone, effectively putting it on DST year-round.

In Canada, the start and end dates of DST vary by province or territory. Here are the DST start and end dates for each province and territory in Canada:

* British Columbia: Second Sunday in March (9:00 AM) to first Sunday in November (2:00 AM)
* Nunavut: Second Sunday in March (8:00 PM) to first Sunday in November (3:00 AM)
* Ontario: First Sunday in March (2:00 AM) to last Sunday in October (2:00 AM) (Note: Some areas of Ontario, such as the James Bay and the northern parts of the Northwest Territories, do not observe DST)
* Quebec: Second Sunday in March (1:00 AM) to last Saturday in October (1:00 AM)

Prompt: when was the national flag of india adopted
Ground truth: The National Flag of India is a horizontal rectangular tricolour of India saffron, white and India green; with the Ashoka Chakra, a 24-spoke wheel, in navy blue at its centre. It was adopted in its present form during a meeting of the Constituent Assembly held on 22 July 1947, and it became the official flag of the Dominion of India on 15 August 1947. The flag was subsequently retained as that of the Republic of India. In India, the term "tricolour" (Hindi: तिरंगा, translit. Tiraṅgā) almost always refers to the Indian national flag. The flag is based on the Swaraj flag, a flag of the Indian National Congress designed by Pingali Venkayya.
[0.000, 0.160, 0.049, 0.112, 0.484] Agent refined response: 15 August 1947 is the date when India adopted its national flag.
[0.000, 0.160, 0.049, 0.112, 0.484] Ori response: 15 August 1947 is the date when India adopted its national flag.

Prompt: who is often associated with printing the first book using moveable type in germany
Ground truth: Johannes Gutenberg of Mainz, Germany is acknowledged as the first to invent a metal movable-type printing system in Europe, the printing press. Gutenberg was a goldsmith familiar with techniques of cutting punches for making coins from moulds. Between 1436 and 1450 he developed hardware and techniques for casting letters from matrices using a device called the hand mould. Gutenberg's key invention and contribution to movable-type printing in Europe, the hand mould, was the first practical means of making cheap copies of letterpunches in the vast quantities needed to print complete books, making the movable-type printing process a viable enterprise.
[0.002, 0.203, 0.034, 0.153, 0.564] Agent refined response: Johannes Gutenberg is often associated with printing the first books using moveable type in Germany.
[0.002, 0.203, 0.034, 0.153, 0.564] Ori response: Johannes Gutenberg is often associated with printing the first books using moveable type in Germany.

Prompt: where do bullets go when fired in the air
Ground truth: Bullets fired into the air usually fall back with terminal velocities much lower than their muzzle velocity when they leave the barrel of a firearm. Nevertheless, people can be injured, sometimes fatally, when bullets discharged into the air fall back down to the ground. Bullets fired at angles less than vertical are more dangerous as the bullet maintains its angular ballistic trajectory and is far less likely to engage in tumbling motion; it therefore travels at speeds much higher than a bullet in free fall.
[0.323, 0.492, 0.373, 0.444, 0.768] Agent refined response: bullets fired into the air usually  fall back with terminal velocities much slower than their muzzle velocity when leaving the barrel of a firearm [1]. This is because the force of gravity causes the bullet to slow down and descend back to the ground.

However, people can still be injured or killed by bullets discharged into the  air, even if they fall back to the ground at slower speeds. This is because the bullet can travel a significant distance before hitting the ground, and the force of the impact can be severe.

To illustrate this point, the knowledge provided states that bullets fired at angles less than  vertical are more dangerous because they maintain their angular ballistic trajectory and are less likely to engage in tumble motion. As a result, these bullets travel at speeds much higher than a  bullet in free fall, making them more likely to cause injury or death if they hit a person or other living thing [1].

In summary, bullets fired into the air can fall back to the ground at slower velocities than their muzzle velocity, but they can still cause harm if they hit a person or other object. It is important to exercise caution and avoid handling or playing with bullets in any situation.
[0.490, 0.596, 0.416, 0.490, 0.787] Ori response: bullets fired into the air usually  fall back with terminal velocities much  lower than their muzzle velocity  when they leave the barrel of  a firearm. This means that the bullets will not travel as fast as they would when fired horizontally or at a target. However, people can still be injured or killed if bullets fall back to the ground after being fired into the air.

Prompt: what was the alliance between great britian russia and france known as
Ground truth: The Triple Entente (from French entente (ɑ̃tɑ̃t) "friendship, understanding, agreement") refers to the understanding linking the Russian Empire, the French Third Republic, and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland after the signing of the Anglo-Russian Entente on 31 August 1907. The understanding between the three powers, supplemented by agreements with Japan and Portugal, was a powerful counterweight to the Triple Alliance of Germany, Austria-Hungary, and Italy.

================================================================================
Prompt: when did the right to buy scheme start
Ground truth: After Margaret Thatcher became Prime Minister in May 1979, the legislation to implement the Right to Buy was passed in the Housing Act 1980. Michael Heseltine, in his role as Secretary of State for the Environment, was in charge of implementing the legislation. Some 6,000,000 people were affected; about one in three actually purchased their housing unit. Heseltine noted that "no single piece of legislation has enabled the transfer of so much capital wealth from the state to the people". He said the right to buy had two main objectives: to give people what they wanted, and to reverse the trend of ever-increasing dominance of the state over the life of the individual.
[0.000, 0.111, 0.048, 0.095, 0.469] Agent refined response: 1980 was when the Right to Buy scheme was introduced.
[0.000, 0.110, 0.048, 0.094, 0.465] Ori response: 1980 was when the Right to Buy scheme was first introduced.

Prompt: who has won the most f1 grand prix
Ground truth: Michael Schumacher holds the record for the most Grand Prix victories, having won 91 times. Lewis Hamilton is second with 62 wins and Alain Prost is third with 51 wins. Michael Schumacher holds the distinction of having the longest time between his first win and his last. He won his first Grand Prix in 1992 at the Belgian Grand Prix, and his last in 2006 at the Chinese Grand Prix, a span of 14 years, 1 month and 1 day. Riccardo Patrese holds the record for the longest period of time between two race wins--more than six-and-a-half years between the 1983 South African Grand Prix and the 1990 San Marino Grand Prix. Mario Andretti had to wait the longest time between his maiden victory at the 1971 South African Grand Prix and his second win--coming five years, seven months and 18 days later at the 1976 Japanese Grand Prix. Sebastian Vettel holds the record for the most consecutive wins, having won nine Grands Prix in a row from the 2013 Belgian Grand Prix to the 2013 Brazilian Grand Prix. Max Verstappen is the youngest winner of a Grand Prix; he was 18 years and 227 days old when he won the 2016 Spanish Grand Prix. Luigi Fagioli is the oldest winner of a Formula One Grand Prix; he was 53 years and 22 days old when he won the 1951 French Grand Prix.
[0.000, 0.096, 0.048, 0.072, 0.554] Agent refined response: Michael Schumacher has won the most Formula One Grand Prix with 91 victories.
[0.119, 0.212, 0.082, 0.131, 0.539] Ori response: 7 drivers have won the most Formula One (F1) Grand Prix races. They are:

1. Michael Schumacher (Germany) - 91 wins
2. Lewis Hamilton (United Kingdom) - 84 wins
3. Sebastian Vettel (Germany) - 53 wins
4. Alain Prost (France) - 52 wins
5. Juan Manuel Fangio (Argentina) - 52 wins
6. Jim Clark (United Kingdom) - 33 wins
7. Ayrton Senna (Brazil) - 41 wins

Therefore, the answer to the user's question is Michael Schumacher, who has won the most F1 Grand Prix races with 91 wins.

Prompt: where does the saying keeping up with the jones come from
Ground truth: The phrase originates with the comic strip Keeping Up with the Joneses, created by Arthur R. "Pop" Momand in 1913. The strip ran until 1940 in The New York World and various other newspapers. The strip depicts the social climbing McGinis family, who struggle to "keep up" with their neighbors, the Joneses of the title. The Joneses were unseen characters throughout the strip's run, often spoken of but never shown. The idiom keeping up with the Joneses has remained popular long after the strip's end.
[0.358, 0.611, 0.527, 0.534, 0.771] Agent refined response: the phrase "Keeping up with the Joneses" originates from the comic strip "Keeping Up with the Joneses" created by Arthur R. "Pop" Momand in 1913, which depicted the social climbing McGinis family struggling to keep up with their neighbors, the Joneses of the title.
[0.371, 0.621, 0.538, 0.545, 0.776] Ori response: the phrase "Keeping up with the Joneses" originates from the comic strip "Keeping Up with the Joneses" created by Arthur R. "Pop" Momand in 1913, which depicted the social climbing McGinis family who struggled to keep up with their neighbors, the Joneses of the title.

Prompt: where does the chinatown bus stop in nyc
Ground truth: Often, ticket booths are walk-up windows on the street, or are located inside restaurants and bakeries throughout a given Chinatown community, although it is not uncommon for tickets to be sold on the street directly. Some lines even simply collect cash payment after passengers have boarded the bus. However, tickets are often sold online, either by the bus companies themselves or by portals and print-outs of confirmation emails are used as tickets. Except in Boston, the lines rarely use stations of their own. Passengers are usually directed to wait along a given curbside for the arrival of the bus, although many companies offer waiting areas at or near the pickup points. Several bus stops are also near major hotels and in the parking areas of major Chinese supermarkets. In New York, several bus lines pick up passengers on a stretch of Forsyth Street at the foot of the Manhattan Bridge in the Little Fuzhou neighborhood within Manhattan's Chinatown. Since 1998, when the New York City Department of Transportation marked the strip a bus layover area, the sidewalk between Division Street and East Broadway has served as a de facto terminal for the Chinatown buses.

Prompt: two main types of research methods used in psychology
Ground truth: Correlational research Descriptive research Experimental research
[0.023, 0.052, 0.021, 0.052, 0.420] Agent refined response: there are two main types of research methods used in Psychology:



1. Correlational Research: This type of research aims to identify the relationship between two or more variables. It involves analyzing the association between different variables and does not imply causality.

2. Experimental Research: This type of research involves manipulating one or more variables and measuring their effect on a dependent variable. It allows researchers to establish cause-and-effect relationships between variables.



Other common research designs and data collection methods in Psychology include:






3. Archival Research: This type of research involves analyzing existing data, such as records or documents, to answer a research question.

4. Case Study: This type of research involves in-depth analysis of a single individual, group, or phenomenon.


5. Computer Simulation (Modeling): This type of research uses computer models to simulate real-world situations and predict the outcome of different variables.

6. Content Analysis: This type of research involves analyzed data from texts, images, or other media to identify patterns or themes.

7. Event Sampling Methodology (ESM): This type of research involves collecting data on a specific event or phenomenon
[0.012, 0.029, 0.000, 0.029, 0.422] Ori response: psychology uses a wide range of research methods, including:

1. Quantitative methods: These methods use numerical data to measure and analyze psychological phenomena. Examples of quantitative methods include surveys, questionnaires, observational studies, and experiments.
2. Qualitative methods: These methods use non-numerical data, such as text, images, and observations, to explore psychological phenomena. Examples include case studies, focus groups, grounded theory, and content analysis.

Prompt: what proposition made the insurance commissioner an elected position
Ground truth: As a result of the passage of Proposition 103 in 1988, the elected office of the California Insurance Commissioner was created in 1991. Previously, the position was held by a person appointed by the Governor. The Insurance Commissioner oversees the Department of Insurance. Democrat Dave Jones won the November 2, 2010 election for California Insurance Commissioner.

Prompt: who was the ottoman governor who led egypt in the years following the napoleonic wars
Ground truth: Egypt under the Muhammad Ali dynasty remained nominally an Ottoman province. It was granted the status of an autonomous vassal state or Khedivate in 1867. Isma'il Pasha and Tewfik Pasha governed Egypt as a quasi-independent state under Ottoman suzerainty until the British occupation of 1882. Nevertheless, the Khedivate of Egypt (1867--1914) remained a de jure Ottoman province until 5 November 1914, when it was declared a British protectorate in reaction to the decision of the Young Turks of the Ottoman Empire to join the First World War on the side of the Central Powers.
[0.007, 0.137, 0.035, 0.137, 0.518] Agent refined response: Hayır Bey was the Ottoman governor of Egypt who led the country during the years following the Napoleonic Wars.
[0.105, 0.263, 0.030, 0.175, 0.541] Ori response: Hayır Bey was the Ottoman governor of Egypt who led the country following the Napoleonic Wars. He was appointed by Sultan Selim III after the conquest of Egypt in 1517 and served as the governor of Egypt until 1805.

Prompt: what role does the president play in foreign affairs
Ground truth: Subject to the advice and consent role of the U.S. Senate, the President of the United States negotiates treaties with foreign nations, but treaties enter into force if ratified by two-thirds of the Senate. The President is also Commander in Chief of the United States Armed Forces, and as such has broad authority over the armed forces. Both the Secretary of State and ambassadors are appointed by the President, with the advice and consent of the Senate. The United States Secretary of State acts similarly to a foreign minister and under Executive leadership is the primary conductor of state-to-state diplomacy.
[0.296, 0.479, 0.224, 0.258, 0.675] Agent refined response: the president plays a significant role in foreign affairs with the advice and consent of the Senate. The president acts as the primary conductor of state-to-state diplomacy and has the power to negotiate treaties and appoint ambassadors. The Senate has a role in ratifying treatIES, and the Supreme Court interprets treaties when cases are brought before it.
[0.404, 0.520, 0.240, 0.249, 0.671] Ori response: the president plays a significant role in foreign affairs with the advice and consent of the Senate. The President acts as the primary conductor of state-to-state diplomacy and has the power to negotiate treaties and appoint ambassadors. The Senate has a role in ratifying treatIES, and the Supreme Court interprets treaties when cases are brought before it. The President is given significant authority in foreign policy decision-making by the Constitution.

Prompt: where are trigger points located in the body
Ground truth: Myofascial trigger points, also known as trigger points, are described as hyperirritable spots in the fascia surrounding skeletal muscle. They are associated with palpable nodules in taut bands of muscle fibers. They are a topic of ongoing controversy, as there is limited data to inform a scientific understanding of the phenomenon. Accordingly, a formal acceptance of myofascial "knots" as an identifiable source of pain is more common among bodyworkers, physical therapists, chiropractors, and osteopathic practitioners. Nonetheless, the concept of trigger points provides a framework which may be used to help address certain musculoskeletal pain.
[0.412, 0.372, 0.144, 0.219, 0.562] Agent refined response: trigger points are located in the muscles and are characterized by localized areas of muscle spasm, pain, and weakness. They are often found in the muscles of the neck, back, and limbs, and can also occur in other muscles throughout the body. The integrated hypothesis theory suggests that trigger points form from excessive releases of acetylcholine, which produces sustained depolarization (abnormal electrical activity) of muscle fibers. This can lead to the formation of trigger points, which are associated with pain deep within a joint where there is no muscle.
[0.248, 0.308, 0.081, 0.183, 0.529] Ori response: trigger points are located in the muscles of the body. More specifically, they are found in the skeletal muscles, which are the muscles that are attached to the bones and help move the body's joints. Trigger points are areas within these muscles where there is a disruption in the normal muscle tissue, leading to pain and stiffness.

The exact location of trigger points can vary depending on the individual and the specific muscle affected. However, they are often found in areas where there is a lot of muscle activity, such as the neck, back, and shoulders. Trigger points in these areas can cause widespread pain and discomfort, as well as limited range of motion and stiffness.

Some common locations for trigger points include:

* The neck and shoulder muscles, which can cause pain and stiffness in the neck, shoulders, and even the arms.
* The back muscles, which can cause pain, stiffness, and limited range of motion in the upper and lower back.
* The abdominal muscles, which can cause pain in the abdomen, back, and even the legs.
* The glute

Prompt: when did equus first appear in fossil record
Ground truth: The first Old World equid fossil was found in the gypsum quarries in Montmartre, Paris, in the 1820s. The tooth was sent to the Paris Conservatory, where it was identified by Georges Cuvier, who identified it as a browsing equine related to the tapir. His sketch of the entire animal matched later skeletons found at the site.

Prompt: sending money home to the native country is an example of
Ground truth: A remittance is a transfer of money by a foreign worker to an individual in his or her home country. Money sent home by migrants competes with international aid as one of the largest financial inflows to developing countries. Workers' remittances are a significant part of international capital flows, especially with regard to labour-exporting countries. In 2014, $436 billion went to developing countries, setting a new record. Overall global remittances totaled $582 billion in 2015. Some countries, such as India and China, receive tens of billions of US dollars in remittances each year from their expatriates and diaspora. In 2014, India received an estimated $70 billion and China an estimated $64 billion.
[0.034, 0.259, 0.175, 0.245, 0.582] Agent refined response: "money sent home by migrants competes as one of the largest financial inlet to developing countries." Therefore, the term used to describe this action is "remittances."
[0.070, 0.359, 0.224, 0.290, 0.645] Ori response: "money sent home by migrants competes  with international aid as one of the most significant financial inflows to developing countries." Therefore, sending money home to the native country is known as "remittances."

Prompt: where does the term pop music come from
Ground truth: According to the website of The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, called Grove Music Online, the term "pop music" "originated in Britain in the mid-1950s as a description for rock and roll and the new youth music styles that it influenced". The Oxford Dictionary of Music states that while pop's "earlier meaning meant concerts appealing to a wide audience. since the late 1950s, however, pop has had the special meaning of non-classical mus (ic), usually in the form of songs, performed by such artists as the Beatles, the Rolling Stones, ABBA, etc". Grove Music Online also states that ". in the early 1960s, (the term) ' pop music ' competed terminologically with beat music (in England), while in the USA its coverage overlapped (as it still does) with that of ' rock and roll '".
[0.358, 0.380, 0.117, 0.231, 0.595] Agent refined response: the term "pop music" originated in the early 20th century as a contraction of the term "popular music." This term was used to describe music that was popular among the masses, as opposed to classical music or jazz, which were considered more highbrow. The term "pop music" was first used in the 1920s to describe the emerging popular music of the time, which was characterized by its catchy melodies and lyrics, and its focus on mass appeal. Over time, the term "pop music" has come to be used to describe a wide range of musical styles, including rock, R&B, hip-hop, and electronic music, among others.
[0.318, 0.388, 0.122, 0.233, 0.599] Ori response: the term "pop music" originated in the early 20th century as a description of popular music, which was seen as a distinct genre from traditional classical music. The term "pop" was used to refer to music that was popular and widely enjoyed by the masses, as opposed to classical music, which was seen as more elite and sophisticated. Over time, the term "pop music" became the commonly used term to refer to popular music, and it has since become a catch-all term for a wide range of musical styles, including rock, hip-hop, electronic, and more.

Prompt: what is foreign account tax compliance act (fatca)
Ground truth: The Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) is a 2010 United States federal law requiring all non-U.S. (' foreign ') financial institutions (FFIs) to search their records for customers with indicia of ' U.S.-person ' status, such as a U.S. place of birth, and to report the assets and identities of such persons to the U.S. Department of the Treasury. FATCA also requires such persons to self-report their non-U.S. financial assets annually to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) on form 8938, which is in addition to the older and further redundant requirement to self-report them annually to the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) on form 114 (also known as' FBAR '). Like U.S. income tax law, FATCA applies to U.S. residents and also to U.S. citizens and green card holders residing in other countries.
[0.553, 0.756, 0.695, 0.756, 0.879] Agent refined response: Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) is a 2010 United States federal law that requires all non-U.S. (foreign) financial institutions (FFIs) to search their records for customers with "indicia of U.S. person status," such as a U.S. place of birth, and to reports the assets and identities of such individuals to the U.S. Department of the Treasury. FATCA also requires such individuals to self-report their non-U.S. financial assets annually to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) on Form 8938, which was in addition to the older Form 114, FATCA.
[0.568, 0.744, 0.658, 0.711, 0.859] Ori response: Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) is a 2010 United States federal law that requires all non-U.S. (foreign) financial institutions (FFIs) to search their records for customers with ties to the U.S., such as a U.S. place of birth, and to  report the assets and identities of these individuals to the U.S. Department of the Treasury. FATCA also requires these individuals to self-report their non-U.S. financial assets annually to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) on Form 8938, which  is in addition to the older Form 114, the FBAR (Foreign Bank Account Report).

The rock crashed into the Dome Shelter, landed on the man and was too heavy for his companion to lift off.

The eruptions were characterized by the emission of steam and ash, and were monitored by volcanologists from the New Zealand Geological Survey. The eruptions were relatively small, with the largest event producing a 200-meter (660-foot) high ash plume.

It is worth noting that Mount Ruapehu is an ongoing volcanic system, and while the 1995-1 nine eruptions were significant, they were not the first time the volcano has erupted in recent history. There have been several smaller eruptions of Mount Ruapehu since then, including a minor eruption in 2003 and a larger eruption in 2014. The volcano is considered to be in a state of continuous unrest, with ongoing geothermal activity and frequent earthquakes.

Prompt: when did they start vaccinating for whooping cough
Ground truth: Before vaccines, an average of 178,171 cases was reported in the U.S., with peaks reported every two to five years; more than 93% of reported cases occurred in children under 10 years of age. The actual incidence was likely much higher. After vaccinations were introduced in the 1940s, pertussis incidence fell dramatically to approximately 1,000 by 1976. Incidence rates have increased since 1980. In 2015, rates in the United States were 20,762 people.
[0.204, 0.186, 0.024, 0.116, 0.484] Agent refined response: 1910 is the year when the zoonotic disease of whooping cough was first identified as a bacterial infection caused by Bordetella pertussis. However, the knowledge gained in the 1930's suggests that the bacteria lost their pathogenic properties when repeatedly spread on agar media, which may have affected the reproducibility of results from different studies.



Therefore, it is not explicitly mentioned when vaccination for whooping cough started, but it is likely that vaccination programs for B. pertussis began in the early 20th century, around the time when the bacterial cause of the disease was identified.
[0.167, 0.163, 0.019, 0.115, 0.491] Ori response: knowledge was gained in the 1930's that the bacteria lost their pathogenic power when repeatedly spread on agar medium. This means that the bacteria, Bordetella pertussis, became less virulent when grown on a nutrient-rich agar plate. This discovery helped explain why different studies had difficulty reproducing results, as the bacteria were not consistently handled before being inoculated.

As for vaccination against whooping cough, the information provided does not mention a specific time period when vaccination against the disease began. However, it is known that vaccination against Bordetella pertussis has been available since the early 20th century, with the first vaccine being developed in the 1910s. The vaccine was initially made from killed bacteria, but later versions were created using inactivated or weakened bacteria to reduce the risk of adverse reactions.

Prompt: is the right to life liberty and the pursuit of happiness in the constitution
Ground truth: The phrase can also be found in Chapter III, Article 13 of the 1947 Constitution of Japan, and in President Ho Chi Minh's 1945 declaration of independence of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam. An alternative phrase "life, liberty, and property", is found in the Declaration of Colonial Rights, a resolution of the First Continental Congress. The Fifth Amendment and Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution declare that governments can not deprive any person of "life, liberty, or property" without due process of law. Also, Article 3 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights reads, "Everyone has the right to life, liberty, and security of person".
[0.333, 0.385, 0.150, 0.236, 0.603] Agent refined response: the phrase "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness" is a well-known phrase in the United States Declaration of Independence. The Declaration states that these three things are among the "unalienable rights" that have been given to all human beingen by their Creator, and that governments are created to protect. However, the Declaration of Independence is not a part of the United States Constitution.



The United States Constitution does not explicitly mention the phrase "life, liberty, or the pursuit of happiness." However, the Constitution does include provisions related to individual rights and freedoms, such as the Bill of Rights, which includes the First Amendment's guarantee of freedom of speech, religion, and the press, as well as the Fourth Amendment's protection against unreasonable searches and seizures. These provisions are often interpreted as protecting the individual's right to life, liberty, and the pursuit happiness.







In summary, while the phrase "life, liberty,and the pursuit of happiness" is not explicitly mentioned in the United States Constitution, the Constitution does include provisions that protect individual rights and freedoms, which are often interpreted as protecting the right to life, liberty
[0.400, 0.400, 0.132, 0.223, 0.588] Ori response: "life, liberty and the pursuit of happines" is a phrase from the United States Declaration of Independence. It is not directly mentioned in the United States Constitution, but the concept of "pursuit of happiness" is interpreted to mean the right to pursue one's own happiness or well-being, which is protected by the Constitution's Bill of Rights.

The Constitution does not explicitly mention the term "pursuit of happiness," but it does provide for individual rights and freedoms, including the right to life, liberty, and property. The Supreme Court has interpreted these rights to include the right to pursue one'se own happiness, as long as it does not infringe on the rights of others.

In summary, while the phrase "life, liberty and the pursuits of happiness" is not in the Constitution, the idea of pursuing one's own happiness is an implied right protected by the Constitution's Bill or Rights.

Prompt: which president of the united states was a boy scout
Ground truth: Eagle Scout is the highest rank one can receive in BSA. A Scout who attains this rank is called an Eagle Scout. Since its introduction in 1911, the Eagle Scout rank has been earned by more than two million young men. Requirements include earning at least 21 merit badges and demonstrating Scout Spirit through the Boy Scout Oath and Law, service, and leadership all before or by age 18. This includes an extensive service project that the Scout plans, organizes, leads, and manages. Eagle Scouts are presented with a medal and a badge that visibly recognizes the accomplishments of the Scout. Additional recognition can be earned through Eagle Palms, awarded for completing additional tenure, leadership, and merit badge requirements. Many famous Americans are Eagle Scouts: astronaut Neil Armstrong, film director Michael Moore, TV host Mike Rowe, Steven Spielberg, Mayor Michael Bloomberg, Secretary of Defense Robert Gates, and President Gerald Ford are just a small sample of Eagle Scouts.
[0.121, 0.183, 0.025, 0.100, 0.468] Agent refined response: all former presidents of the United States serve as honorary vice presidents of the Boy Scouts of America for their lifetimes. Therefore, all former presidents have been or will be honorary vice presidents of the organization.

Prompt: what is the full scientific name for the e. coli bacteria
Ground truth: Escherichia coli (/ˌɛʃɪˈrɪkiə ˈkoʊlaɪ/; also known as E. coli) is a Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic, rod-shaped, coliform bacterium of the genus Escherichia that is commonly found in the lower intestine of warm-blooded organisms (endotherms). Most E. coli strains are harmless, but some serotypes can cause serious food poisoning in their hosts, and are occasionally responsible for product recalls due to food contamination. The harmless strains are part of the normal flora of the gut, and can benefit their hosts by producing vitamin K, and preventing colonization of the intestine with pathogenic bacteria, having a symbiotic relationship. E. coli is expelled into the environment within fecal matter. The bacterium grows massively in fresh fecal matter under aerobic conditions for 3 days, but its numbers decline slowly afterwards.
[0.002, 0.151, 0.028, 0.096, 0.502] Agent refined response: the full scientific name for the Escherichia coli (E. coli) bacteria is Escherichia coli (molecular biology).
[0.000, 0.153, 0.028, 0.097, 0.511] Ori response: the full scientific name for the Escherichia coli (E. coli) bacteria is Escherichia coli.

The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Foundation was established on April 20, 1983, by Atlantic Records founder and chairman Ahmet Ertegun. In 1986, Cleveland was chosen as the Hall of Fame's permanent home. Since opening in September 1995, the "Rock Hall"--part of the city's redeveloped North Coast Harbor--has hosted more than 10 million visitors and had a cumulative economic impact estimated at more than $1.8 billion.

Ground truth: In ecology, a habitat is the kind of natural environment in which a particular species of organism lives. It is characterized by both physical and biological features. A species' habitat is those places where it can find food, shelter, protection and mates for reproduction.
[0.049, 0.138, 0.000, 0.103, 0.498] Agent refined response: communities of similar organisms found in a specific environment are called "ecosystems" or "biocoenosis".
[0.102, 0.151, 0.000, 0.132, 0.533] Ori response: communities of similar organisms found in a specific environment are called "ecosystems."

Ecosystems are communities of living organisms (such as plants, animals, and microorganisms) that interact with one another and their environment. These interactions include nutrient cycling, energy flow, and the exchange of gases and other chemicals. The living organisms in an ecosystem are interconnected and interdependent, and their interactions with their environment shape the structure and function of the ecosystem.

Ecosystems can be found in a variety of environments, including forests, grasslands, deserts, oceans, and even urban areas. Each ecosystem has its unique characteristics, such as the types of plants and animals that live there, the amount of sunlight and water it receives, and the types of nutrients and pollutants that are present.

Ecosystems are important for a variety of reasons, including providing food, fiber, and other resources for humans, supporting biodiversity and ecological resilience, and regulating the Earth's climate and weather patterns. Understanding ecosystems and their interactions with the environment is essential for managing and

Prompt: bowler to take hattrick in both inning in test match
Ground truth: A player has taken two hat-tricks in the same Test match only once. Playing for Australia against South Africa in the first match of the 1912 Triangular Tournament at Old Trafford, Manchester, England, leg spinner Jimmy Matthews took a hat-trick in South Africa's first and second innings, both taken on 28 May 1912. He completed both hat-tricks by dismissing South Africa's Tommy Ward. Only three other cricketers have taken more than one Test hat-trick: Australian off spinner Hugh Trumble (two years apart, between the same teams at the same ground), Pakistani fast bowler Wasim Akram (just over a week apart, in consecutive matches between the same teams) and English fast bowler Stuart Broad. Three players have taken a hat-trick on their Test debut: English medium pace bowler Maurice Allom in 1930, New Zealand off-spinner Peter Petherick in 1976, and Australian pace bowler Damien Fleming in 1994. Geoff Griffin took the fewest total Test wickets of any player who recorded a hat-trick, taking only eight wickets in his entire Test career. During the match in which he took his hat-trick, Griffin was repeatedly called for throwing by the umpires and never bowled again in a Test match. Australian Peter Siddle is the only bowler to take a hat-trick on his birthday, and Bangladeshi off spinner Sohag Gazi is the only player to score a century and take a hat-trick in the same Test match.
[0.092, 0.204, 0.122, 0.153, 0.615] Agent refined response: 4 bowlers have taken hat-tricks in both innings of a Test match:

1. Jimmy Matthews (Australia) - against South Africa in the 1912 Triangular Tournament at Old Trafford, Manchester, England.
2. Ian Botham (England) - against India at Trent Bridge, Nottingham, England in 1977.
3. Kapil Dev (India) - against Pakistan at Faisalabad, Pakistan in 1978.
4. Shane Warne (Australia) - against Pakistan at Melbourne Cricket Ground, Melbourne, Australia in 1999.

Prompt: who is the new york state senate majority leader
Ground truth: There was a lengthy dispute over the leadership of the Senate during June and July 2009. On June 8, 2009, Democrats Hiram Monserrate and Pedro Espada, Jr., joined the 30 Republican members of the State Senate to attempt to issue a motion to replace current Majority Leader Malcolm Smith with Minority Leader Dean Skelos. Following the precedent of 1913, the temporary presidency and the majority leadership would have been separated again under this scenario. Since the office of Lieutenant Governor fell vacant after Lt. Gov. David Paterson succeeded to the governorship upon Gov. Eliot Spitzer's resignation, the majority leaders (Bruno, Skelos and Smith) have acted as lieutenant governors. The motions put forward on June 8 also sought to select Pedro Espada as Temporary President of the State Senate, which would have installed him as acting lieutenant governor. The Democrats have disputed the legitimacy of the motions put forward on June 8. The New York State Senate has been providing a running update of the legal proceedings since June 11, 2009. The dispute ended July 9, 2009, when Senator Espada announced he would return to the Democratic caucus and take on the position of majority leader, while it was also announced that former majority leader Malcolm Smith had assumed the title of president pro tempore, and John Sampson would serve as Democratic conference leader with the understanding he would assume the presidency at an undetermined future date. Following the 2010 election and the Republican victory in the Senate, Senator Dean Skelos from Long Island served as both Temporary President and Majority Leader, but resigned in May 2015 in the midst of corruption charges. The current majority leader, or president, is John J. Flanagan.

Prompt: when did the soviet union start and end
Ground truth: The Soviet Union (Russian: Сове́тский Сою́з, tr. Sovetsky Soyuz, IPA: (sɐˈvjɛt͡skjɪj sɐˈjus) (listen)), officially the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (Russian: Сою́з Сове́тских Социалисти́ческих Респу́блик, tr. Soyuz Sovetskikh Sotsialisticheskikh Respublik, IPA: (sɐˈjus sɐˈvjɛtskjɪx sətsɨəljɪsˈtjitɕɪskjɪx rjɪˈspubljɪk) (listen)), abbreviated as USSR (Russian: СССР, tr. SSSR), was a socialist state in Eurasia that existed from 1922 to 1991. Nominally a union of multiple national Soviet republics, its government and economy were highly centralized. The country was a one-party state, governed by the Communist Party with Moscow as its capital in its largest republic, the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic. The Russian nation had constitutionally equal status among the many nations of the union but exerted de facto dominance in various respects. Other major urban centres were Leningrad, Kiev, Minsk, Alma-Ata and Novosibirsk. The Soviet Union was one of the five recognized nuclear weapons states and possessed the largest stockpile of weapons of mass destruction. It was a founding permanent member of the United Nations Security Council, as well as a member of the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) and the leading member of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA) and the Warsaw Pact.
[0.075, 0.282, 0.051, 0.173, 0.451] Agent refined response: the Soviet Union was formed with the unification of Russian, Transcaucasian, Ukrainian, and Byelorussian Republics in  1922. Stalin came to power in the mid-1920s after Lenin's death in 1024 and initiated a centrally-planned economy, leading to a period of rapid industrialization, and collectivization.



Therefore, the Soviet Union started in 1922 and ended in 1991, with the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the establishment of independent states.
[0.182, 0.308, 0.071, 0.167, 0.448] Ori response: the Soviet Union was formed through the unification of the Russian, Transcaucasian, Ukrainian, and Byelorussian Republics in 1922.

Stalin came to power in the mid-1920s after Lenin's death in 1024.

The period of rapid industrialization and collectvization began during Stalin's rule, and the late 1930s saw the Great Purge, which resulted in the removal of Stalin's opponents within and outisde of the party through arbitrary arrests and persecutions, resulting in an estimated 6 million deaths.

Therefore, the dates for when the Soviet Union started and ended are:

Started: 1922 (formation of the Soviet Union)
Ended: 1991 (dissolution of the Soviet Union)

Prompt: where does cleavage of the peptide bond by chymotrypsin occur
Ground truth: Chymotrypsin (EC 3.4. 21.1, chymotrypsins A and B, alpha-chymar ophth, avazyme, chymar, chymotest, enzeon, quimar, quimotrase, alpha-chymar, alpha-chymotrypsin A, alpha-chymotrypsin) is a digestive enzyme component of pancreatic juice acting in the duodenum where it performs proteolysis, the breakdown of proteins and polypeptides. Chymotrypsin preferentially cleaves peptide amide bonds where the side-chain of the amino acid N-terminal to the scissile amide bond (the P position) is a large hydrophobic amino acid (tyrosine, tryptophan, and phenylalanine). These amino acids contain an aromatic ring in their sidechain that fits into a ' hydrophobic pocket ' (the S position) of the enzyme. It is activated in the presence of trypsin. The hydrophobic and shape complementarity between the peptide substrate P sidechain and the enzyme S binding cavity accounts for the substrate specificity of this enzyme. Chymotrypsin also hydrolyzes other amide bonds in peptides at slower rates, particularly those containing leucine and methionine at the P position.
[0.000, 0.103, 0.023, 0.080, 0.532] Agent refined response: the cleavage of the peptid bond by chymotrypsins occurs in the digestive systems of various organisms.
[0.018, 0.184, 0.031, 0.143, 0.574] Ori response: chymotrypsin facilitates the cleavage  of peptide bonds by hydrolysis reaction, which occurs extremely slowly in the absence of  a catalyst. Therefore, the cleavage of the peptid bond by chymotryps in occurs in the digestive systems of  many organisms.

Prompt: why did the colonists have a problem with the tea act of 1773
Ground truth: The Tea Party was the culmination of a resistance movement throughout British America against the Tea Act, which had been passed by the British Parliament in 1773. Colonists objected to the Tea Act because they believed that it violated their rights as Englishmen to "No taxation without representation", that is, to be taxed only by their own elected representatives and not by a British parliament in which they were not represented. In addition, the well-connected East India Company had been granted competitive advantages over colonial tea importers, who resented the move and feared additional infringement on their business. Protesters had successfully prevented the unloading of taxed tea in three other colonies, but in Boston, embattled Royal Governor Thomas Hutchinson refused to allow the tea to be returned to Britain.
[0.302, 0.588, 0.417, 0.485, 0.767] Agent refined response: the colonists objected to the Tea Act of 1773 because they believed it violated their rights as Englishmen to "no taxation without representation," meaning they should only be taxed by their own elected representatives and never by a British Parliament in which they were not represented. They also resented the competitive advantages granted to the well-connected East India Company, which threatened their business.
[0.194, 0.514, 0.376, 0.448, 0.728] Ori response: the colonists objected to the Tea Act of 1773 because they believed it violated their rights as Englishmen to "no taxation without representation," meaning they were only willing to be taxed by their own elected representatives and were not willing to be taxed by a British Parliament in which they were not represented.
