Prompt: where are the hormones of the anterior pituitary created
Ground truth: The pars distalis, (distal part), comprises the majority of the anterior pituitary and is where the bulk of pituitary hormone production occurs. The pars distalis contains two types of cells including chromophobe cells and chromophil cells. The chromophils can be further divided into acidophils (alpha cells) and basophils (beta cells). These cells all together produce hormones of the anterior pituitary, and release them into the blood stream.
[0.324, 0.325, 0.092, 0.234, 0.546] Agent refined response: hormones of the anterior psuedogland are created in the following locations:

1. Hypothalamus: The hypothalamus produces corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) and vasopressin.
2. Anterior pituitary gland: The hypothalamus releases CRH and vasopressin, which activates the release of ACTH from the anterior pituitary.
3. Adrenal cortex: Stress-induced release of CRH and vasopressin from the anterior pituitary leads to the production of glucocorticoids such a cortisol by the adrenal cortex.

Therefore, the hormones of the anterior hypophysis are created in the hypothalamus, anterior pituitary gland, and adrenal cortex.
[0.232, 0.258, 0.065, 0.183, 0.528] Ori response: the hormones of the anterior pituiary gland are created through the following process:

1. Stress: Stress induces the release of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) and vasopressin from the hypthalamus.
2. Activation of the adrenal cortex: CRH and vasopressin activate the release of adrenocortcotropic hormone (ACTH) from the anterior pituitary Gland.
3. Production of glucocorticoids: ACTH acts on the adrenal cortexto produce glucocorticoids, such as cortisol.
4. Negative feedback: The glucocorticoids produced by the adrenal cortex act back on the anterior pituiaty gland and the hypothalamu with negative feedback to slow the production  of CRH.

Therefore, the hormones of the anteriorpituitary gland are created in the hypothalamus and the adrenal cortex through a complex interplay of hormones and feedback mechanisms.

Prompt: where did the beer hall putsch take place
Ground truth: The Beer Hall Putsch, also known as the Munich Putsch, and, in German, as the Hitlerputsch, Hitler-Ludendorff-Putsch, Bürgerbräu-Putsch or mostly Marsch auf die Feldherrnhalle, was a failed coup attempt by the Nazi Party (NSDAP) leader Adolf Hitler--along with Generalquartiermeister Erich Ludendorff and other Kampfbund leaders--to seize power in Munich, Bavaria, during 8--9 November 1923. About two thousand Nazis marched to the centre of Munich, where they confronted the police, which resulted in the death of 16 Nazis and four police officers. Hitler was not wounded during the clash, although he locked his left arm with the right arm of Max Erwin von Scheubner-Richter who, when he was shot and killed, pulled Hitler to the pavement with him. Hitler escaped immediate arrest and was spirited off to safety in the countryside. After two days, Hitler was arrested and charged with treason.
[0.002, 0.154, 0.060, 0.142, 0.491] Agent refined response: the Beer Hall Putsch took place in Munich, Bavaria, Germany. The exact location of the event was Marienplatz in Munich.
[0.002, 0.154, 0.060, 0.142, 0.491] Ori response: the Beer Hall Putsch took place in Munich, Bavaria, Germany. The exact location of the event was Marienplatz in Munich.

Prompt: who said beware of the ides of march
Ground truth: In modern times, the Ides of March is best known as the date on which Julius Caesar was assassinated in 44 BC. Caesar was stabbed to death at a meeting of the Senate. As many as 60 conspirators, led by Brutus and Cassius, were involved. According to Plutarch, a seer had warned that harm would come to Caesar no later than the Ides of March. On his way to the Theatre of Pompey, where he would be assassinated, Caesar passed the seer and joked, "The Ides of March are come", implying that the prophecy had not been fulfilled, to which the seer replied "Aye, Caesar; but not gone." This meeting is famously dramatised in William Shakespeare's play Julius Caesar, when Caesar is warned by the soothsayer to "beware the Ides of March." The Roman biographer Suetonius identifies the "seer" as a haruspex named Spurinna.
[0.026, 0.284, 0.195, 0.205, 0.641] Agent refined response: it was the "seer" or "haruspex" named Spurinna who said "Beware the ides of March" to Julius Caesar on his way to the theater of Pompey, where he would be assasinated.
[0.117, 0.375, 0.221, 0.292, 0.657] Ori response: it was the "seer" or "haruspex" named Spurinna who warned Julius Caesar of the impending danger on the Ides of March.

In William Shakespeare's play "Julius Caesar," the line "Beware the Ides of March" is spoken by the soothsayer or seer, who is identified as Spurinna.

Prompt: how tall is the tallest building in las vegas
Ground truth: The city of Las Vegas, Nevada and its surrounding unincorporated communities in the Las Vegas Valley are the sites of more than 160 high-rises, 42 of which stand taller than 400 feet (122 m). The tallest structure in the city is the Stratosphere Tower, which rises 1,149 feet (350 m) just north of the Las Vegas Strip. The tower is also the tallest observation tower in the United States. Since the Stratosphere Tower is not fully habitable, however, it is not considered a building. The tallest building in Las Vegas is The Drew Las Vegas, which rises 735 feet (224 m) and was topped out in November 2008. This building, however, is currently on hold. The tallest completed building in the city is the 52-story Palazzo, which rises 642 feet (196 m) and was completed in 2007.
[0.004, 0.247, 0.163, 0.173, 0.623] Agent refined response: 735 feet (224 m) is the height of the currently on-hold building, making it the tallest completed building in Las Vegas.
[0.004, 0.236, 0.201, 0.224, 0.708] Ori response: the tallest completed building in Las Vegas is the Palazzo, which rises 624 feet (196 m) and was completed in 2017.

Prompt: who explored waters of cuba the bahamas and hispaniola
Ground truth: In 1492 Christopher Columbus sailed from Spain on his first voyage with three ships, the Niña, the Pinta, and the flagship, Santa Maria, seeking a direct route to Asia. On 12 October 1492 Columbus reached an island in the Bahamas and claimed it for Spain, an event long regarded by Europeans as the ' discovery ' of America. This island was called Guanahani by the Lucayan, and San Salvador by the Spanish. The identity of the first American landfall by Columbus remains controversial, but many authors accept Samuel E. Morison's identification of Columbus' San Salvador as what was later called Watling (or Watling's) Island. Its name has been officially changed to San Salvador. Columbus visited several other islands in the Bahamas before sailing to present-day Cuba and afterwards to Hispaniola.
[0.001, 0.188, 0.082, 0.107, 0.569] Agent refined response: Christopher Columbus explored the waters of Cuba, the Bahamas, and Hispaniola during his first voyage in 1492.
[0.001, 0.188, 0.082, 0.107, 0.569] Ori response: Christopher Columbus explored the waters of Cuba, the Bahamas, and Hispaniola during his first voyage in 1492.

Prompt: where do the secretory cells of endocrine glands secrete their products
Ground truth: Exocrine glands are glands that produce and secrete substances onto an epithelial surface by way of a duct. Examples of exocrine glands include sweat, salivary, mammary, ceruminous, lacrimal, sebaceous, and mucous. Exocrine glands are one of two types of glands in the human body, the other being endocrine glands, which secrete their products directly into the bloodstream. The liver and pancreas are both exocrine and endocrine glands; they are exocrine glands because they secrete products--bile and pancreatic juice--into the gastrointestinal tract through a series of ducts, and endocrine because they secrete other substances directly into the bloodstream.
[0.341, 0.371, 0.019, 0.181, 0.599] Agent refined response: endocrine gland secretory cells secrete their products through the following mechanisms:

1. Serous cells secrete proteins, including enzymes. Examples include gastric chief cells and Paneth cells.
2. Mucous cells secrete mucin. Examples include Brunner's glands, esaphageal glands, and plyoric glands.
3. Mixed glands secrete both proteins and mucin. Examples include the salivary glands, with the parotid gland being 20% serous.
4. Holocrine secretion - the entire cell disintegrates and excretes its substance. Examples include sebaceous glands of skin and nose.
5. Apocrine secretion - a portion of the cell membranes that contain excretion buds off.

So, endocrine gland secretary cells secrete their products through different mechanisms depending on the type of cell.
[0.333, 0.366, 0.019, 0.169, 0.601] Ori response: secretory cells of endocrine cells secrete their products through the following mechanisms:

1. Serous cells secrete proteins, including enzymes. Examples include gastric chief cells and Paneth cells.
2. Mucous cells secrete mucin. Examples include Brunner's glands, esaphageal glands, and plyoric glands.
3. Mixed glands secrete both proteins and mucus. Examples include the salivary glands, although the Parotid gland is 20% predominantly serous.
4. Apocrine secretion - a portion of the cell membranes containing excretion buds off.
5. Holocrine secretion - the entire cell disintegrates and excretes its substance. Examples include sebaceous glands of skin and nose.

Therefore, the secretory cells of endocrin glands secrete their products through different mechanisms depending on the type of cell.

Prompt: who was the first signatory of the israeli declaration of independence
Ground truth: As leader of the Yishuv, David Ben-Gurion was the first person to sign. The declaration was due to be signed by all 37 members of Moetzet HaAm. However, twelve members could not attend, eleven of them trapped in besieged Jerusalem and one abroad. The remaining 25 signatories present were called up in alphabetical order to sign, leaving spaces for those absent. Although a space was left for him between the signatures of Eliyahu Dobkin and Meir Vilner, Zerach Warhaftig signed at the top of the next column, leading to speculation that Vilner's name had been left alone to isolate him, or to stress that even a communist agreed with the declaration. However, Warhaftig later denied this, stating that a space had been left for him (as he was one of the signatories trapped in Jerusalem) where a Hebraicised form of his name would have fitted alphabetically, but he insisted on signing under his actual name so as to honour his father's memory and so moved down two spaces. He and Vilner would be the last surviving signatories, and remained close for the rest of their lives. Of the signatories, two were women (Golda Meir (Meyerson/Myerson) and Rachel Cohen-Kagan).
[0.000, 0.111, 0.084, 0.111, 0.476] Agent refined response: David Ben-Gurion was the first person to  sign the Israeli Declaration of Independence.
[0.000, 0.159, 0.098, 0.124, 0.524] Ori response: David Ben-Gurion was the first person to signing the Israeli Declaration of Independence, held by Moshe Sharett as leader of the Yishuv.

Prompt: how long did it take to build the great pyramid of egypt
Ground truth: Egyptologists believe the pyramid was built as a tomb for the Fourth Dynasty Egyptian pharaoh Khufu (often Hellenized as "Cheops") and was constructed over a 20-year period. Khufu's vizier, Hemiunu (also called Hemon) is believed by some to be the architect of the Great Pyramid. It is thought that, at construction, the Great Pyramid was originally 280 Egyptian Royal cubits tall (146.5 metres (480.6 ft)), but with erosion and absence of its pyramidion, its present height is 138.8 metres (455.4 ft). Each base side was 440 cubits, 230.4 metres (755.9 ft) long. The mass of the pyramid is estimated at 5.9 million tonnes. The volume, including an internal hillock, is roughly 2,500,000 cubic metres (88,000,000 cu ft).
[0.229, 0.257, 0.058, 0.161, 0.508] Agent refined response: 14 years is the estimated time span for the construction of the Great Pyramid of Giza, with a peak workforce of roughly 30,000 people. This estimate is based on a modern construction management study in association with Egyptologists, which suggests that the total project required an average of 14,500 workers and a peak of around 40,000 people. Without the use of pulleys, wheel, or iron tools, the ancient Egyptians used critical path analysis methods to complete the construction of the Great Pyramids from start to finish in approximately 30 years.

How long did it take to build the Great Pyramid of Gizza?

Without the use of pulleypwheels, or iron tools, the ancient Egpytians used
[0.115, 0.271, 0.063, 0.146, 0.520] Ori response: 14 years is the estimated time span for the construction of the Great Pyramid of Giza, with a peak workforce of roughly 30,000 people. This estimate is based on a modern construction management study in association with Egyptologists, and suggests that the pyramid was completed from start-to-finish in approximately 10 years without the use of pulleys or iron tools.

Prompt: a type of basic rock popular in the 1980s
Ground truth: By the late 1960s "classic rock" period, a number of distinct rock music subgenres had emerged, including hybrids like blues rock, folk rock, country rock, raga rock, and jazz-rock, many of which contributed to the development of psychedelic rock, which was influenced by the countercultural psychedelic and hippie scene. New genres that emerged included progressive rock, which extended the artistic elements; glam rock, which highlighted showmanship and visual style; and the diverse and enduring subgenre of heavy metal, which emphasized volume, power, and speed. In the second half of the 1970s, punk rock reacted by producing stripped-down, energetic social and political critiques. Punk was an influence in the 1980s on new wave, post-punk and eventually alternative rock. From the 1990s alternative rock began to dominate rock music and break into the mainstream in the form of grunge, Britpop, and indie rock. Further fusion subgenres have since emerged, including pop punk, electronic rock, rap rock, and rap metal, as well as conscious attempts to revisit rock's history, including the garage rock/post-punk and synth-pop revivals at the beginning of the 2000s.
[0.009, 0.100, 0.018, 0.072, 0.504] Agent refined response: 1980s heavy metal bands such as Judas Priest, UFO, Motorhead, and Rainbow from Britain, KISS, Ted Nugent, and Blue Oyster Cult from the US, Rush from Canada, and Scorpions from Germany helped shape the subgenre.
[0.110, 0.201, 0.031, 0.131, 0.569] Ori response: 1980s heavy metal bands such as Judas Priest, UFO, Motorhead, and Rainbow from Britain, KISS, Ted Nugent, and Blue Oyster Cult from the US, Rush from Canada, and Scorpions from Germany, developed the characteristic sounds and styles that helped shape the subgenre. These bands took up elements of fantasy, symphonic, and medieval interests from their progressive and blues-rock roots, and introduced facets of the goth and modal harmony, creating a "darker" sound.

Prompt: where did the rulers of the qing dynasty originate
Ground truth: The dynasty was founded by the Jurchen Aisin Gioro clan in Manchuria. In the late sixteenth century, Nurhaci, originally a Ming vassal, began organizing "Banners", military-social units that included Jurchen, Han Chinese, and Mongol elements. Nurhaci formed the Jurchen clans into a unified entity, which he renamed as the Manchus. By 1636, his son Hong Taiji began driving Ming forces out of Liaodong and declared a new dynasty, the Qing. In 1644, peasant rebels led by Li Zicheng conquered the Ming capital, Beijing. Rather than serve them, Ming general Wu Sangui made an alliance with the Manchus and opened the Shanhai Pass to the Banner Armies led by the regent Prince Dorgon, who defeated the rebels and seized the capital. Resistance from the Southern Ming and the Revolt of the Three Feudatories led by Wu Sangui extended the conquest of China proper for nearly four decades and was not completed until 1683 under the Kangxi Emperor (r. 1661--1722). The Ten Great Campaigns of the Qianlong Emperor from the 1750s to the 1790s extended Qing control into Inner Asia. The early rulers maintained their Manchu ways, and while their title was Emperor, they used "Bogd khaan" to the Mongols and they were patrons of Tibetan Buddhism. They governed using Confucian styles and institutions of bureaucratic government and retained the imperial examinations to recruit Han Chinese to work under or in parallel with Manchus. They also adapted the ideals of the tributary system in dealing with neighboring territories.
[0.000, 0.084, 0.015, 0.046, 0.477] Agent refined response: the rulers of the Qing dynasty originated from Manchuria, a region in northeastern China.
[0.000, 0.062, 0.016, 0.039, 0.469] Ori response: the rulers of the Qing dynasty originated from Manchuria.

Prompt: what is the name of the weapon the grim reaper carries
Ground truth: The Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities of Sir William Smith claims that the scythe, known in Latin as the falx foenaria as opposed to the sickle, the falx messoria, was used by the ancient Romans. According to ancient Greek mythology it was believed that Gaea the Greek goddess mother of Titans gave ' a sickle was made out of the strongest metal ' to her youngest son ' Kronos' who is also youngest of Titans (also known as God of Harvest) to seek vengeance against her Husband Ouranos for Torturing their oldest sons. To illustrate this, Smith cites an image of Saturn holding a scythe, from an ancient Italian cameo. The Grim Reaper and the Greek Titan Cronus were often depicted carrying or wielding a scythe. According to Jack Herer and "Flesh of The Gods" (Emboden, W.A., Jr., Praeger Press, NY, 1974.); the ancient Scythians grew hemp and harvested it with a hand reaper that we still call a scythe.

Prompt: who wrote when a man loves a woman
Ground truth: "When a Man Loves a Woman" is a song written by Calvin Lewis and Andrew Wright and first recorded by Percy Sledge in 1966 at Norala Sound Studio in Sheffield, Alabama. It made number one on both the Billboard Hot 100 and R&B singles charts. Singer and actress Bette Midler recorded the song 14 years later and had a Top 40 hit with her version in 1980. In 1991, Michael Bolton recorded the song and his version peaked at number one on both the Billboard Hot 100 chart and the Billboard Adult Contemporary Singles chart.

Prompt: who represents the insured in the investigation of a claim
Ground truth: Claims adjuster (claim adjuster), or claims handler (claim handler), investigates insurance claims by interviewing the claimant and witnesses, consulting police and hospital records, and inspecting property damage to determine the extent of the company's liability. In the United Kingdom, Ireland, Australia, South Africa, the Caribbean and New Zealand the term loss adjuster is used. Other claims adjusters who represent policyholders may aid in the preparation of an insurance claim.
[0.184, 0.327, 0.130, 0.200, 0.605] Agent refined response: a claims adjuster or public adjusters represent the insured in the investigation of claims. They do not practice law, but rather assess and evaluate the covered injuries or damages to determine the extent of coverage according to the applicable law.
[0.275, 0.336, 0.114, 0.176, 0.600] Ori response: a claims adjuster or public adjusters represents the insured in the investigation and settlement of an insurance claim. They do not engage in the practice of law, but rather follow best insurance practices to evaluate covered injuries and damages, negotiate a settlement according to applicable law, and identify coverages for which the  insured is covered.

Prompt: when does a dieback or population crash occur
Ground truth: In population dynamics and population ecology, overshoot occurs when a population temporarily exceeds the long term carrying capacity of its environment. The environment usually has mechanisms in place to prevent overshoot. For example, plants are only able to regenerate and regrow a few times after being consumed before completely dying off. The consequence of overshoot is called a collapse, a crash or a die-off in which there is a decline in population density. The entire sequence or trajectory undergone by the population and its environment together is often termed ' overshoot-and-collapse '.
[0.306, 0.370, 0.087, 0.222, 0.605] Agent refined response: a dieback or population crash occurs when the rate of reproduction is higher than the death rate, leading to an increase in population density. This can happen due to lag effects, where the population grows rapidly before the death rate catches up. Overshoot can occur when reproduction rates remain high relative to the death rate, leading to a decline in population density and a subsequent collapse of the population.
[0.407, 0.522, 0.277, 0.360, 0.707] Ori response: a die-off or population crash occurs when the rate of death exceeds the rate of reproduction, leading to a decline in population density. This can happen when there are lag effects, meaning that reproduction rates remain high relative to the death rate, leading to an overshoot in population growth. The entire sequence or trajectory undergoned by the population and its environment together are termed "overshoot-and-collapse."

Prompt: where do you get male pattern baldness from
Ground truth: Male pattern hair loss is believed to be due to a combination of genetics and the male hormone dihydrotestosterone. The cause in female pattern hair loss remains unclear.
[0.106, 0.207, 0.040, 0.158, 0.586] Agent refined response: male pattern baldness, also known as androgenic or male pattern alopecia, is a common condition in which men experience hair loss due to the presence of androgens (male hormones) in their bodies. The hair loss typically begins with a receding hairline and/or a thinning of hair on the top of the head.


There are several factors that can contribute to the development of male pattern baldness, including:

1. Genetics: Male pattern baldness tends to run in families, suggesting that there may be a genetic component to the condition.
2. Aging: Male pattern baldness is more common in older men, with the risk of hair loss increasing with age.
3. Hormonal imbalance: Androgens, such as testosterone and dihydrotestosterone (DHT), play a role in the development of male pattern baldness. An imbalance of these hormones can lead to hair loss.
4. Stress: Prolonged periods of stress can contribute to hair loss in some men.
5. Poor diet: A diet that is deficient in essential nutrients, such as iron, zinc, or biotin, can lead to hair loss
[0.097, 0.186, 0.050, 0.147, 0.601] Ori response: male pattern baldness, also known as androgenic or male pattern alopecia, is a common condition in which men experience hair loss in a specific pattern, typically starting with the temples and crown of the head. It is caused by a combination of genetic and hormonal factors, with the primary hormone involved being dihydrotestosterone (DHT).

There are several studies that have investigated the genetic and hormonal factors that contribute to male pattern baldness. For example, one study found that the presence of a specific genetic variant in the AR gene, which codes for the androgen receptor, is associated with an increased risk of developing male pattern baldness. Another study found that levels of DHT are significantly higher in men with male pattern baldness compared to those without the condition.

It is important to note that male pattern baldness is a complex condition, and multiple factors are likely involved in its development. While genetics and hormones are thought to play a significant role, other factors such as age, stress, and overall health may also contribute to the condition.

Prompt: what states do not allow daylight savings time
Ground truth: Daylight saving time in the United States is the practice of setting the clock forward by one hour during the warmer part of the year, so that evenings have more daylight and mornings have less. Most areas of the United States observe daylight saving time (DST), the exceptions being Arizona (except for the Navajo, who do observe daylight saving time on tribal lands), Hawaii, and the overseas territories of American Samoa, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, Puerto Rico, and the United States Virgin Islands. The Uniform Time Act of 1966 established the system of uniform Daylight Saving Time throughout the US.
[0.309, 0.423, 0.247, 0.372, 0.650] Agent refined response: 4 states in the United States do not observe Daylight Saving Time (DST):

1. Arizona (except for the Navajo Nation, who do observe DST on tribal lands)
2. Hawaii
3. American Samoa
4. Guam



So, the answer to the user's question is: Arizona, Hawaii, American Samoa, and Guam do not observe Daylight Saving time.
[0.267, 0.380, 0.218, 0.354, 0.652] Ori response: 4 states in the United States do not observe Daylight Saving Time (DST):

1. Arizona (except for the Navajo Nation, who do observe DST on tribal lands)
2. Hawaii
3. American Samoa
4. Guam

These states are exempt from observing DST, meaning they do not change their clocks to take advantage of daylight during the summer months.

Both companies specialize in Mexican-style grilled chicken and were founded by Juan Francisco Ochoa. Ochoa established the first El Pollo Loco restaurant in Guasave, Sinaloa, Mexico, in the mid-1970s, and then expanded his chain into the United States in 1980. Ochoa then sold his U.S. restaurants in 1983, which became El Pollo Loco, Inc., while keeping the ones in Mexico, which became El Pollo Loco, S.A. de C.V. Both companies have since occupied non-overlapping global territories, and have offered different fare.

Prompt: who won the nobel peace prize for 2017
Ground truth: The 2017 Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to the International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN) "for its work to draw attention to the catastrophic humanitarian consequences of any use of nuclear weapons and for its ground-breaking efforts to achieve a treaty-based prohibition on such weapons," according to the Norwegian Nobel Committee announcement on October 6, 2017. The award announcement acknowledged the fact that "the world's nine nuclear-armed powers and their allies" neither signed nor supported the treaty-based prohibition known as the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons or nuclear ban treaty, yet in an interview Committee Chair Berit Reiss-Andersen told reporters that the award was intended to give "encouragement to all players in the field" to disarm. The award was hailed by civil society as well as governmental and intergovernmental representatives who support the nuclear ban treaty, but drew criticism from those opposed. At the Nobel Peace Prize award ceremony held in Oslo City Hall on December 10, 2017, Setsuko Thurlow, an 85-year-old survivor of the 1945 atomic bombing of Hiroshima, and ICAN Executive Director Beatrice Fihn jointly received a medal and diploma of the award on behalf of ICAN and delivered the Nobel lecture.
[0.000, 0.119, 0.074, 0.100, 0.520] Agent refined response: ican (International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons) won the Nobel Peace Prize for 2017.
[0.000, 0.127, 0.092, 0.118, 0.540] Ori response: the International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN) won the Nobel Peace Prize for 2017.

Prompt: what are the 3 layers of the meninges
Ground truth: The meninges (/məˈnɪndʒiːz/, singular: meninx (/ˈmiːnɪŋks/or/ˈmɛnɪŋks/), from Ancient Greek: μῆνιγξ, translit. mēninx, lit. ' membrane ', adjectival: meningeal/məˈnɪndʒəl/) are the three membranes that envelop the brain and spinal cord. In mammals, the meninges are the dura mater, the arachnoid mater, and the pia mater. Cerebrospinal fluid is located in the subarachnoid space between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater. The primary function of the meninges is to protect the central nervous system.
[0.361, 0.256, 0.091, 0.192, 0.485] Agent refined response: the 3 layers of the meninge are:

1. Dura mater: the outermost layer, characterized by multiple interdigitated cell processes, no extracellural collagen, and significant extracelullar spaces.
2. Middle region: a mostly fibrous portion consisting of two layers: the endosteal layer, closest to the calvaria (skullcap), and the inner meningeal layer closer to the brain.
3. Pia mater: the innermost layer, composed of dense fibrous tissues and inner surface covered by capillaries.
[0.323, 0.304, 0.093, 0.175, 0.520] Ori response: the 3 layers of the meninx are:

1. Dura mater (tough mother): a thick, durable membrane closest to the skull and vertebrate. It is a loosely arranged, fiberous layer of cells with multiple interdigitating cell processes, little extracellular collagen, significant amounts of ground substance, and no distinctive nervous plexuses.
2. Arachnoid mater (spider-like): a delicate, fibrous membrane that is the middle layer of the meninges. It is a well-vascularized structure composed of thin, delicate, branching fibers that give it a spider-like appearance.
3. Pia mater (delicate mother): the innermost layer of the meninges, a delicate, vascular membrane that closely adheres to the surface of the brain and spinal cord. It is composed of a thin layer of flattened epithelial cells that form a continuous surface with the neural tissue.

Prior to this, the only way to taste pineapples was where they were cultivated, which limited their availability to a small elite with access to glasshouses.

Prompt: where are the cones in the eye located
Ground truth: Cone cells, or cones, are one of three types of photoreceptor cells in the retina of mammalian eyes (e.g. the human eye). They are responsible for color vision and function best in relatively bright light, as opposed to rod cells, which work better in dim light. Cone cells are densely packed in the fovea centralis, a 0.3 mm diameter rod-free area with very thin, densely packed cones which quickly reduce in number towards the periphery of the retina. There are about six to seven million cones in a human eye and are most concentrated towards the macula. The commonly cited figure of six million cone cells in the human eye was found by Osterberg in 1935. Oyster's textbook (1999) cites work by Curcio et al. (1990) indicating an average close to 4.5 million cone cells and 90 million rod cells in the human retina.
[0.382, 0.374, 0.099, 0.236, 0.596] Agent refined response: cones are located in various parts of the retina, but are much less numerous than rods. However, they are greatly outnumbered by rods in most parts of the eye, but they are more concentrated in the fovea. Specifically, cones are located in the following areas of the eye:

1. Fovea: Cones are most densely packed in the fovea, which is located in the center of the retina.
2. Periphery: Cones are also found in the peripheral areas of the retina, but in smaller numbers than in the fovea.



In terms of their exact location within the eye, cones are typically 40-50 micrometers long and have a diameter that varies from 0.5 to 4.0 micrometers, with the smallest and most tightly packed cones located at the center of the eye in the fovea. The spacing of the cones is slightly larger than the others.

Please let me know if you have any further questions!
[0.186, 0.344, 0.110, 0.208, 0.586] Ori response: cones are located in the fovea, which is a specific area in the center of the retina. The fovea is a small, specialized area in the retina that is responsible for high-resolution vision and color perception. Cones are much less numerous than rods, but they greatly outnumber rods in the  fovea. In the fovea, cones are arranged in a specific pattern, with the s cone spacing slightly larger than the others.

Prompt: what stage of the star life cycle is the sun in
Ground truth: The Sun is about halfway through its main-sequence stage, during which nuclear fusion reactions in its core fuse hydrogen into helium. Each second, more than four million tonnes of matter are converted into energy within the Sun's core, producing neutrinos and solar radiation. At this rate, the Sun has so far converted around 100 times the mass of Earth into energy, about 0.03% of the total mass of the Sun. The Sun will spend a total of approximately 10 billion years as a main-sequence star. The Sun is gradually becoming hotter during its time on the main sequence, because the helium atoms in the core occupy less volume than the hydrogen atoms that were fused. The core is therefore shrinking, allowing the outer layers of the Sun to move closer to the centre and experience a stronger gravitational force, according to the inverse-square law. This stronger force increases the pressure on the core, which is resisted by a gradual increase in the rate at which fusion occurs. This process speeds up as the core gradually becomes denser. It is estimated that the Sun has become 30% brighter in the last 4.5 billion years. At present, it is increasing in brightness by about 1% every 100 million years.
[0.000, 0.088, 0.054, 0.071, 0.484] Agent refined response: the sun is currently in the main sequence stage of its life cycle.
[0.071, 0.310, 0.121, 0.176, 0.630] Ori response: the sun is currently in the main sequence stage of its life cycle. This stage is marked by the star's stable and continuous nuclear fusion reactions in its core, which provide the energy that powers the star's luminosity. The sun has been in this stage for about 4.6 billion years and will remain here for another 5 billion years or so before entering the red giant branch phase.

Prompt: when does april fools day end at noon
Ground truth: In Poland, prima aprilis ("1 April" in Latin) as a day of jokes is a centuries-long tradition. It is a day in which many jokes are told; various hoaxes--sometimes very sophisticated--are prepared by people, media (which often cooperate to make the "information" more credible) and even public institutions. Serious activities are usually avoided, and generally every word said on April 1st can be a lie, or a joke. The conviction for this is so strong that the Polish anti-Turkish alliance with Leopold I signed on April 1, 1683, was backdated to March 31. However, for some in Poland prima aprilis ends at noon of April 1st, and prima aprilis jokes after that hour are considered inappropriate and not classy.
[0.372, 0.366, 0.057, 0.179, 0.550] Agent refined response: 1st of April, also known as April Fools' Day, is not a public holiday in Any country. However, the custom of setting aside a Day for playing practical jokes and spreading Hoaxes has been popular since the 19th Century.

Therefore, there is no specific time or duration for April Fools' Day, as it is not a public holiday and can be celebrated at any time or duration.

However, some people may choose to end their April Fools' Day pranks or jokes at noon, as a way to mark the end of the day and signal the start of a new one. But this is not a fixed or universal time, and individuals or groups can choose to end their pranks whenever they wish.
[0.277, 0.357, 0.059, 0.203, 0.558] Ori response: 1st of April, commonly known as April Fools' Day, is not a public holiday in  any country. It is a day when people in some European and Western countries commemorate by playing practical jokes and spread hoaxes. The day is not a public holiday, and there is no specific time frame when the pranks should end. It is a day for people to have fun and play jokes on each other, and the pranks can continue throughout the day until people decide to stop.

Prompt: name of black man in to kill a mockingbird
Ground truth: Thomas "Tom" Robinson is an African-American who is put on trial for the rape of a white woman, Mayella Ewell. Atticus is assigned to defend him, and stands up to a lynch mob intent on exacting their own justice against him before the trial begins. Tom's left arm is crippled and useless, the result of an accident with a cotton gin when he was a child. Atticus uses this fact as the cornerstone of his defense strategy, pointing out that the nature of Mayella's facial injuries strongly suggest a left-handed assailant. Tom testifies that he had frequently helped Mayella with household chores because he felt sorry for her and the family's difficult life-a statement that shocks the all-white, male jury. Despite Atticus' skilled defense, the jury's racial prejudices lead them to find Tom guilty. Prompt: where is connective tissue found in the body
Ground truth: Connective tissue (CT) is one of the four basic types of animal tissue, along with epithelial tissue, muscle tissue, and nervous tissue. It develops from the mesoderm. Connective tissue is found in between other tissues everywhere in the body, including the nervous system. In the central nervous system, the three outer membranes (the meninges) that envelop the brain and spinal cord are composed of connective tissue. They support and protect the body. All connective tissue consists of three main components: fibers (elastic and collagenous fibers), ground substance and cells. Not all authorities include blood or lymph as connective tissue because they lack the fiber component. All are immersed in the body water.
[0.389, 0.546, 0.354, 0.404, 0.708] Agent refined response: connective tissue is found throughout the body, including the nervous and circulatory systems. In the central nervous system, the meninges, which are the three outer membranes that envelop the brain and spine, are composed of connective tissue and provide support and protection to the brain and spinal cord. Connective tissue is also found in other tissues and organs throughout the body, such as the heart, blood vessels, lungs, liver, and kidneys.
[0.319, 0.535, 0.353, 0.407, 0.714] Ori response: connective tissue is found throughout the body, including the nervous and circulatory systems. In the central nervous system, the meninges, which are the three outer membranes that envelop the brain and spine, are composed of connective tissue and provide support and protection. Connective tissue is also found in other parts of the body, such as the skin, muscles, and organs.

Prompt: how many times have the winter olympics been in the usa since 1924
Ground truth: The Winter Olympics has been hosted on three continents by twelve different countries. The Games have been held four times in the United States (in 1932, 1960, 1980 and 2002); three times in France (in 1924, 1968 and 1992); and twice each in Austria (1964, 1976), Canada (1988, 2010), Japan (1972, 1998), Italy (1956, 2006), Norway (1952, 1994), and Switzerland (1928, 1948). Also, the Games have been held just once each in Germany (1936), Yugoslavia (1984), Russia (2014) and South Korea (2018). The IOC has selected Beijing, China, to host the 2022 Winter Olympics and the host of the 2026 Winter Olympics will be selected in September 2019. As of 2018, no city in the southern hemisphere has applied to host the cold-weather-dependent Winter Olympics, which are held in February at the height of the southern hemisphere summer.

Prompt: explain the function of the peripheral nervous system
Ground truth: The peripheral nervous system (PNS) is one of the two components of the nervous system, the other part is the central nervous system (CNS). The PNS consists of the nerves and ganglia outside the brain and spinal cord. The main function of the PNS is to connect the CNS to the limbs and organs, essentially serving as a relay between the brain and spinal cord and the rest of the body. Unlike the CNS, the PNS is not protected by the vertebral column and skull, or by the blood--brain barrier, which leaves it exposed to toxins and mechanical injuries. The peripheral nervous system is divided into the somatic nervous system and the autonomic nervous system. In the somatic nervous system, the cranial nerves are part of the PNS with the exception of the optic nerve (cranial nerve II), along with the retina. The second cranial nerve is not a true peripheral nerve but a tract of the diencephalon. Cranial nerve ganglia originated in the CNS. However, the remaining ten cranial nerve axons extend beyond the brain and are therefore considered part of the PNS. The autonomic nervous system is an involuntary control of smooth muscle and glands. The connection between CNS and organs allows the system to be in two different functional states: sympathetic and parasympathetic.
[0.313, 0.366, 0.172, 0.263, 0.613] Agent refined response: the peripheral nervous system (PNS) has two primary functions:

1. Regulation of involuntary actions: The PNS is responsible for regulating involuntary actions such as heart rate, digestion, and breathing. It does this through the autonomic nervous system, which is divided into the sympathetic nervous system and the parasympathetic nervous system. The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for the "fight or flight" response, while the parasympathetic nervosa system is responsible for the "rest and digest" response.

2. Sensory functions: The PNS also plays a role in sensory functions, such as transmitting sensory information from the body to the brain. This includes sensations such as pain, temperature, touch, and pressure.

In summary, the PNS regulates involuntary actions and sensory functions, while the central nervous system (CNS) is responsible for controlling voluntary actions and cognitive functions.
[0.423, 0.438, 0.233, 0.306, 0.664] Ori response: the peripheral nervous system (PNS) is a part of the nervous system that connects the central nervous system (CNS) to the rest of the body. It consists of sensory receptors, nerves, and ganglia that transmit signals between the CNS and the rest of the body. The PNS is responsible for the following functions:

1. Sensory Functions: The PNS transmits sensory information from the body to the CNS, which helps us perceive the environment around us. For example, the PNS carries information from our skin, muscles, and organs to the brain, allowing us to feel pain, temperature, touch, and other sensations.
2. Autonomic Functions: The PNS regulates the autonomic nervous system, which controls involuntary functions such as heart rate, blood pressure, digestion, and respiration. The PNS helps maintain homeostasis by controlling the autonomic nervous system.
3. Motor Functions: The PNS transmitted signals from the CNS to muscles and glands throughout the body, allowing for voluntary movements and secretions.
4. Regulation of Body Functions

Prompt: what is the approximate volume of the brain
Ground truth: Studies on human brain size, largely based on participants of European ancestry, tend to find an average adult brain volume of 1260 cubic centimeters (cm) for men and 1130 cm for women. There is, however, substantial variation between individuals; one study of 46 adults, aged 22--49 years and of mainly European descent, found an average brain volume of 1273.6 cm for men, with a range of 1052.9 to 1498.5 cm, and 1131.1 cm for women, with a range of 974.9 to 1398.1 cm.
[0.166, 0.266, 0.071, 0.140, 0.576] Agent refined response: the average brain volume of modern humans is approximately 1,300-1,450 cm (or 1.3-1.45 liters). However, it is important to note that brain size can vary significantly among individuals and populations, and there is ongoing debate among researchers about the significance of brain size changes in human evolution.
[0.195, 0.331, 0.117, 0.201, 0.571] Ori response: the average brain volume of modern humans is approximately 1,300-1,450 cm3 (cubic centimeters). However, it is important to note that brain size can vary significantly among individuals and populations, and there is no definitive answer to the question of the average brain volume of modern humans.

Prompt: where did the santa fe trail take emigrants
Ground truth: The Santa Fe Trail was a 19th-century transportation route through central North America that connected Independence, Missouri with Santa Fe, New Mexico. Pioneered in 1821 by William Becknell, it served as a vital commercial highway until the introduction of the railroad to Santa Fe in 1880. Santa Fe was near the end of the El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro which carried trade from Mexico City.
[0.164, 0.375, 0.106, 0.271, 0.574] Agent refined response: the Santa Fe Trail took emigrants from the state of Missouri in the United States to Santa Fe, which was in the northern Mexican state of Nuevo México.

Prompt: who was the first chief minister of west bengal
Ground truth: Since 1947, there have been eight Chief Ministers of West Bengal. The first was Prafulla Chandra Ghosh of the Indian National Congress, who was succeeded by his party-mates Dr Bidhan Chandra Roy and Prafulla Chandra Sen. A decade of instability followed, marred by fractious coalition governments and frequent impositions of President's rule. The instability ended with 1977 election victory of the Communist Party of India (Marxist) (CPM). Headed by Jyoti Basu, the CPM-led Left Front government was in office for over 23 years (1977--2000). Left rule in West Bengal continued for another 10 years under Buddhadeb Bhattacharya, before its defeat in the 2011 election by the Trinamool Congress. Appointed on 20 May 2011, Trinamool leader Mamata Banerjee is the current incumbent, the state's first woman chief minister.
[0.000, 0.154, 0.085, 0.112, 0.552] Agent refined response: Prafulla Chandra Ghosh was the first Chief Minister of West Bengal.

Prompt: what do the 3 dots mean in math
Ground truth: In logical argument and mathematical proof, the therefore sign (∴) is generally used before a logical consequence, such as the conclusion of a syllogism. The symbol consists of three dots placed in an upright triangle and is read therefore. It is encoded at U + 2234 ∴ therefore (HTML & # 8756; &there4;). For common use in Microsoft Office hold the ALT key and type "8756". While it is not generally used in formal writing, it is used in mathematics and shorthand. It is complementary to U + 2235 ∵ because (HTML & # 8757;).
[0.316, 0.341, 0.024, 0.153, 0.536] Agent refined response: 3 dots in a triangle shape are used to signify "therefore" in the 18th century. However, there wasn't much consistency in how the triangle was oriented, and the notation became rare in continental Europe but remained popular in the British Isles.
 In the 19th century, the three-dot notation for "therefore" originated, and it remains popular in the British Isles. An example of its use in a syllogism is:

All gods are immortal.
Zeus is a god.
Zeus is immortal.

X + 1 = 6.
[0.265, 0.306, 0.043, 0.170, 0.560] Ori response: 3 dots in a triangle shape are used to signify "therefore" in the 18th century. However, there wasn't much consistency in how the triangle was oriented, and the notation became rare in continental Europe but remained popular in the British Isles. In the 19th century, the three-dot notation for "therefore" originated, and it is still used in some contexts, such as in a syllogism:

All gods are immortal.
Zeus is a god.
Zeus is immortal.

In math, the three dots are not typically used to signify "therefore." They are often used to indicate a sequence of mathematical operations or to separate lines of mathematical expressions. For example:

1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 = 15

Or:

2 + 3 + 4 = 9

In summary, the three dots in a triangle shape are not a standard mathematical notation, and their meaning can vary depending on the context in which they are used.

Prompt: who is recognized as the founder of islam
Ground truth: According to tradition, the Islamic prophet Muhammad was born in Mecca around the year 570. His family belonged to the Quraysh. When he was about forty years old, he began receiving what Muslims consider to be divine revelations delivered through the angel Gabriel, which would later form the Quran, enjoining him to proclaim a strict monotheistic faith, warn his compatriots of the impending Judgement Day, and castigate social injustices of his city. Muhammad's message won over a handful of followers and was met with increasing opposition from notables of Mecca. In 618, after he lost protection with the death of his influential uncle Abu Talib, Muhammad took flight to the city of Yathrib (subsequently called Medina) where he was joined by his followers. Later generations would count this event, known as the hijra, as the start of the Islamic era.
[0.000, 0.054, 0.014, 0.054, 0.481] Agent refined response: Muhammad is recognized as the founder of Islam.
[0.000, 0.054, 0.014, 0.054, 0.481] Ori response: Muhammad is recognized as the founder of Islam.

Prompt: what is the maximum data rate for the 802.11a standard select one
Ground truth: The 802.11 a standard uses the same data link layer protocol and frame format as the original standard, but an OFDM based air interface (physical layer). It operates in the 5 GHz band with a maximum net data rate of 54 Mbit/s, plus error correction code, which yields realistic net achievable throughput in the mid-20 Mbit/s.

It is revealed later that Sasuke is the sole survivor of the once-powerful Uchiha clan of Konohagakure. He, at the age of seven, survived the massacre of his clan perpetrated by his brother, Itachi, who spared Sasuke's life because he did not consider him worth killing. Sasuke seeks strong fighting opponents to reassure himself his power is growing.

Prompt: where does the term dog and pony show come from
Ground truth: The term was originally used in the United States in the late-19th and early-20th centuries to refer to small traveling circuses that toured through small towns and rural areas. The name derives from the common use of performing dogs and ponies as the main attractions of the events. Performances were generally held in open-air arenas, such as race tracks or public spaces in localities that were too small or remote to attract larger, more elaborate performers or performances. The most notorious was "Prof. Gentry's Famous Dog & Pony Show," started when teenager Henry Gentry and his brothers started touring in 1886 with their act, originally entitled "Gentry's Equine and Canine Paradox." It started small, but evolved into a full circus show. Other early dog and pony shows included Morris' Equine and Canine Paradoxes (1883) and Hurlburt's Dog and Pony Show (late 1880s).
[0.251, 0.340, 0.112, 0.190, 0.579] Agent refined response: 

The term "dog and pony show" is believed to have originated in the United States in the mid-20th century, and it is used to describe a political or media event that is perceived as being superficial or insincere. The term is thought to have originated from the idea that politicians or other public figures would use a "dog and pony show" to distract the public from more important issues or to present a false image of themselves or their policies. The term is often used in a negative context to suggest that someone is trying to deceive or manipulate others through empty rhetoric or showmanship.
[0.255, 0.335, 0.137, 0.183, 0.583] Ori response: 

The term "dog and pony show" is believed to have originated in the United States in the mid-20th century. The exact origin of the term is unclear, but it is thought to have been used in the entertainment industry to refer to a low-quality or unimpressive show or performance. The term "dog" may have been used to refer to something that is old or outdated, while "pony" may have been used to refer something that is small or unimpressive. Over time, the term "dog and pony show " has been used more broadly to refer to any unimpressive or uninteresting event or performance.

[0.023, 0.054, 0.014, 0.054, 0.436] Agent refined response: psychology portal, there are a wide range of research methods used in psychology, and these methods vary by:

1. Quantitative research methods: These methods involve the collection and analysis of numerical data, often using statistical analysis. Examples of quantitative research methods include:
	* Surveys and questionnaires
	* Experiments, often with separate treatment and control group
	* Correlational research
	* Neuroimaging and other psychophy physiological methods
	
	* Observational studies, can be naturalistic or controlled
2. Qualitative research methods: These methods involve collecting and analyzing non-numerical data, such as text, images, and observations. Examples of qualitative research methods include:
	• Case studies
	
	• Content analysis
	• Diary studies
	• Ecological momentary assessment (EMA)
	• Field experiments

	• Interviews, can be structured or unstricted

	• Meta-analysis
	• Neuroimaging and other psych physiological methods
	• Observational studies, can be natural or controlled
	• Quasi-experiments

Each of these methods has its own strengths and limitations, and researchers use a
[0.031, 0.094, 0.000, 0.071, 0.439] Ori response: psychology portal, there are two main types of research methods used in Psychology:

1. Quantitative research methods: These methods involve the collection and analysis of numerical data, often using statistical techniques to analyze the data. Examples of quantitative research methods include surveys, questionnaires, experiments, and correlational studies.
2. Qualitative research methods: These methods involve collecting and analyzing non-numerical data, such as text, observations, and interviews. Examples of qualitative research methods include case studies, grounded theory, and content analysis.

Prompt: where does us highway 1 start and end
Ground truth: U.S. Route 1 (US 1) is a major north--south U.S. Highway that serves the East Coast of the United States. It runs 2,369 miles (3,813 km), from Fort Kent, Maine, at the Canada--US border, south to Key West, Florida, making it the longest north--south road in the United States. US 1 is generally paralleled by Interstate 95 (I-95), though the former is significantly farther west (inland) between Jacksonville, Florida, and Petersburg, Virginia. The highway connects most of the major cities of the East Coast--including Miami, Jacksonville, Richmond, Washington, D.C., Baltimore, Philadelphia, New York City and Boston, passing from the Southeastern United States to New England.
[0.063, 0.265, 0.067, 0.132, 0.509] Agent refined response: 

US Highway 1 starts in Miami, Florida, and ends in Fort Kent, Maine.

Here is a summary of the starting and ending points of US Highway 1:

Starting Point: Miami, Florida
Ending Point: Fort Kent, Maine

However, parts of US 1, such as US 9, US 13, US 15, US 17, and US 21, occupy cor ridors closer to the ocean, and in some cases, substantial portions are east of US 1. For example, US 13 terminates only a few miles west of US 1 after crossing it in Falls Township, PA, with over 99.5% of it running east of US 1.

Prompt: first jnanpith award was an autor of which language
Ground truth: G. Sankara Kurup, (3 June 1901, Nayathode, Kingdom of Cochin (now in Ernakulam district, Kerala, India)--2 February 1978, Vappalassery, Angamaly, Ernakulam district, Kerala), better known as Mahakavi G (The Great Poet G), was the first winner of the Jnanpith Award, India's highest literary award. He won the prize in 1965 for his collection of poems in Malayalam Odakkuzhal (The Bamboo Flute, 1950). With part of the prize money he established the literary award Odakkuzhal in 1968. He was also the recipient of the Soviet Land Nehru Award, in 1967, and the Padma Bhushan in 1968. His poetry collection Viswadarshanam won the Kerala Sahitya Akademi Award in 1961 and Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award in 1963.

Prompt: what does it mean to be on parole
Ground truth: Parole is a temporary release of a prisoner who agrees to certain conditions before the completion of the maximum sentence period, originating from the French parole ("voice, spoken words"). The term became associated during the Middle Ages with the release of prisoners who gave their word.
[0.140, 0.210, 0.046, 0.155, 0.524] Agent refined response: being on parole means that a person who has been convicted of a crime and sentenced to serve time in a federal correctional facility, has the opportunity to be released from prison early, subject to certain conditions and supervision by a parole officer. However, parole is not guaranteed and can be denied or revoked if the offender violates the terms of their parole.

In the case of federal offenses, parole is typically available for offenders who have been sentenced to serve no less than 2 years. However, the sentencing judge has the discretion to impose a longer period of parole ineligibility, particularly for offenders convicted of serious crimes such as first-degree murder.

It's worth noting that parole is not the same as probation, which is a type of community supervision that is available for offenders who have been convicted of less serious crimes. Parole is a form of early release from prison, while probation is a type of community supervision granted to offenders who have not been convicted of a crime.
[0.217, 0.310, 0.039, 0.168, 0.523] Ori response: being on parole means that a prisoner who has been released from prison after serving a sentence of at least two years, is supervised by a parole officer in the community. During this time, the parolee is required to follow certain rules and conditions, such as reporting regularly to their parole officer, maintaining employment or attending school, and avoiding contact with certain people or places. Parole is not guaranteed, and the length of parole supervision can vary depending on the type of offense and the sentence imposed. In some cases, such as first-degree murder, parole may not be available until after 25 years have passed since the conviction.

Prompt: how long is training camp for nfl players
Ground truth: In the National Football League, training camp refers to the time before the season commences. During this time, teams will sometimes congregate at an outside location, usually a university, to conduct training camp for at least the first few weeks. This is similar to baseball's spring training.
[0.245, 0.270, 0.029, 0.142, 0.514] Agent refined response: NFL training camps typically last for several weeks, with the exact duration varying depending on the team and the player's position. The first half of training camp is usually focused on conditioning and individual drills, while the latter half leads directly into the exhibition season. With NFL training camps starting in late July, the biggest concern has been dehydration, as highlighted by the death of Minnesota Vikings player Korey Stringer in 2001 due to dehydration and heat stroke. As a result, the NFL has changed their training policies to prioritize player safety.
[0.357, 0.330, 0.053, 0.174, 0.543] Ori response: NFL training camps typically last for several weeks, with the exact duration varying depending on the team and the player's position. The first half of training camp is usually around 2-3 weeks, while the second half leads directly into the exhibition season and can last up to 2-3 weeks as well. In total, an NFL training camp can last anywhere from 4-6 weeks.

Prompt: who is the founder of google and when was it founded
Ground truth: Google Inc. is an American multinational technology company that specializes in Internet-related services and products. These include online advertising technologies, search, cloud computing, software, and hardware. Google was founded in 1998 by Larry Page and Sergey Brin while they were Ph. D. students at Stanford University, in California. Together, they own about 14 percent of its shares, and control 56 percent of the stockholder voting power through supervoting stock. They incorporated Google as a privately held company on September 4, 1998. An initial public offering (IPO) took place on August 19, 2004, and Google moved to its new headquarters in Mountain View, California, nicknamed the Googleplex. In August 2015, Google announced plans to reorganize its various interests as a conglomerate called Alphabet Inc. Google, Alphabet's leading subsidiary, will continue to be the umbrella company for Alphabet's Internet interests. Upon completion of the restructure, Sundar Pichai was appointed CEO of Google; he replaced Larry Page, who became CEO of Alphabet.

Prompt: when did beryl markham fly across the atlantic
Ground truth: When Markham decided to take on the Atlantic crossing, no female pilot had yet flown non-stop from Europe to New York, and no woman had made the westward flight solo, though several had died trying. Markham hoped to claim both records. On 4 September 1936, she took off from Abingdon, England. After a 20-hour flight, her Vega Gull, The Messenger, suffered fuel starvation due to icing of the fuel tank vents, and she crash-landed at Baleine Cove on Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia, Canada. She became the first person to make it from England to North America non-stop from east to west. She was celebrated as an aviation pioneer.
[0.027, 0.239, 0.086, 0.141, 0.546] Agent refined response: Beryl Markham was the first woman to successfully cross the Atlantic from east to west non-stop. However, there is no specific information provided about when she did this.
[0.000, 0.141, 0.079, 0.109, 0.520] Ori response: Beryl Markham successfully flew across the Atlantic from east to west non-stop in 1930.

Prompt: what does the sun represent on the uruguay flag
Ground truth: The horizontal stripes on the flag represent the nine original departments of Uruguay, based on the U.S flag, where the stripes represent the original 13 colonies. The first flag designed in 1828 had 9 light blue stripes; this number was reduced to 4 in 1830 due to visibility problems from distance. The Sun of May represents the May Revolution of 1810; according to the historian Diego Abad de Santillán, the Sun of May is a figurative sun that represents Inti, the sun god of the Inca religion. It also appears in the Flag of Argentina and the Coat of Arms of Bolivia.

Prompt: when does a limit of a function not exist
Ground truth: Formal definitions, first devised in the early 19th century, are given below. Informally, a function f assigns an output f (x) to every input x. We say the function has a limit L at an input p: this means f (x) gets closer and closer to L as x moves closer and closer to p. More specifically, when f is applied to any input sufficiently close to p, the output value is forced arbitrarily close to L. On the other hand, if some inputs very close to p are taken to outputs that stay a fixed distance apart, we say the limit does not exist.
[0.281, 0.258, 0.087, 0.153, 0.530] Agent refined response: 

A limit of a function does not exist in the following situations:

1. As $s$ approaches an open interval of the form $(-\infty,a)$ (i.e., to the left of $a$) or $(a,\infty)$ (i.e., tothe right of $a$), the limit of a real-valued function $f(x)$ may not exist.
2. When $x$ approaches a half-closed interval's included endpoint (e.g., $x$ approaches $0$ from below in the interval $(0,1)$).

In these situations, the limit of the function may not exist due to the lack of a well-defined value for the limit as $s$ approaches the specified point.
[0.216, 0.239, 0.080, 0.159, 0.523] Ori response: 

A limit of a function does not exist in the following cases:

1. When the domain of the function is not a closed interval.
2. When the limit is taken as the variable approaches a point in the domain of the function from an open interval.
3. When the limit is taken as an open interval of the form (a, ∞) or (−∞, a), where a is a real number.
4. When the function has a vertical asymptote.
5. When the function has a discontinuity at the point where the limit is taken.
6. When the function has a jump discontinuity at the point where limit is taken.
7. When the function has a cusp discontinuity at the point where limits are taken.
8. When the function has a infinite limit as the variable approaches a point in its domain.

It is important to note that these are some of the common cases where a limit may not exist, but there could be other cases depending on the specific function and its properties.

Neal Avron handled production duties. Commenting on the record's lyrical themes, Wentz said the lyrics were about "the anxiety and depression that goes along with looking at your own life." In support of their release the group headlined tours worldwide and played at various music festivals. For their Black Clouds and Underdogs tour the album was re-released as From Under the Cork Tree (Limited "Black Clouds and Underdogs" Edition), featuring new songs and remixes.

Prompt: where does eye of the round roast come from
Ground truth: A round steak is a beef steak from the "round", the rear leg of the cow. The round is divided into cuts including the eye (of) round, bottom round, and top round, with or without the "round" bone (femur), and may include the knuckle (sirloin tip), depending on how the round is separated from the loin. This is a lean cut and it is moderately tough. Lack of fat and marbling makes round dry out when cooked with dry-heat cooking methods like roasting or grilling. Round steak is commonly prepared with slow moist-heat methods including braising, to tenderize the meat and maintain moisture. The cut is often sliced thin, then dried or smoked at low temperature to make jerky.
[0.005, 0.224, 0.128, 0.140, 0.557] Agent refined response: an eye of round roast comes from the round cut of beef, which is located in the rear leg of the cow.
[0.005, 0.224, 0.128, 0.140, 0.557] Ori response: an eye of round roast comes from the round cut of beef, which is located in the rear leg of the cow.

Furthermore, the 5 and 5S design was regarded as "long been the golden child of Apple phone design and a benchmark for phones in general" (with the 5S's gold finish adding a premium touch to the 5's already well-regarded look), while the succeeding 6 and 6S design was less critically acclaimed as it "felt a little bit wrong, as though you were holding a slick $650 bar of soap". The iPhone 5 was described as "elegance rooted in the way the aluminum and glass work together. It felt streamlined, yet substantial, which is different from iPhone 6, which feels substantial in size alone. Plus, unlike the ubiquitous rounded corners of the 6, iPhone 5 didn't really look like anything else on the market at the time". However, the iPhone 5/5S design was not suited to scaling up, in contrast to the iPhone 6/6S which could better accommodate the growing consumer trend towards larger screen sizes and indeed spawned the 6/6S Plus phablet models. When Apple discontinued the iPhone 5S, it was replaced by the iPhone SE which outwardly appears almost identical to the 5S even as the SE's internal hardware has been upgraded significantly.

Prompt: who gave the famous objective co relative theory
Ground truth: The theory of the objective correlative as it relates to literature was largely developed through the writings of the poet and literary critic T.S. Eliot, who is associated with the literary group called the New Critics. Helping define the objective correlative, Eliot's essay "Hamlet and His Problems", republished in his book The Sacred Wood: Essays on Poetry and Criticism discusses his view of Shakespeare's incomplete development of Hamlet's emotions in the play Hamlet. Eliot uses Lady Macbeth's state of mind as an example of the successful objective correlative: "The artistic ' inevitability ' lies in this complete adequacy of the external to the emotion.", as a contrast to Hamlet. According to Eliot, the feelings of Hamlet are not sufficiently supported by the story and the other characters surrounding him. The objective correlative's purpose is to express the character's emotions by showing rather than describing feelings as discussed earlier by Plato and referred to by Peter Barry in his book Beginning Theory: An Introduction to Literary and Cultural Theory as ". perhaps little more than the ancient distinction (first made by Plato) between mimesis and diegesis." (28). According to Formalist critics, this action of creating an emotion through external factors and evidence linked together and thus forming an objective correlative should produce an author's detachment from the depicted character and unite the emotion of the literary work. The "occasion" of E. Montale is a further form of correlative.
[0.000, 0.151, 0.091, 0.121, 0.546] Agent refined response: T.S. Eliot is associated with the literary group and is largely responsible for developing the theory of the objective correlative in literature.
[0.000, 0.151, 0.091, 0.121, 0.546] Ori response: T.S. Eliot is associated with the literary group and is largely responsible for developing the theory of the objective correlative in literature.
================================================================================
Prompt: when does canada switch to daylight savings time
Ground truth: In regions where daylight saving time is used, it commences on the second Sunday of March, and standard time restarts on the first Sunday in November.
[0.298, 0.475, 0.282, 0.425, 0.641] Agent refined response: 

Canada switches to Daylight Saving Time (DST) on the second Sunday in March at 2:00 a.m. local time, and returns to Standard Time on the first Sunday in November at 2:00 a..m. local time. This means that the exact date of the switch varies depending on the province or territory.
[0.286, 0.442, 0.262, 0.395, 0.646] Ori response: 

Canada switches to Daylight Saving Time (DST) on the second Sunday in March at 2:00 a.m. local time and returns to Standard Time on the first Sunday in November at 2:00 a .m. local time. This means that during DST, the clocks are set forward one hour to make better use of daylight during the summer months.

Prompt: where do bullets go when fired in the air
Ground truth: Bullets fired into the air usually fall back with terminal velocities much lower than their muzzle velocity when they leave the barrel of a firearm. Nevertheless, people can be injured, sometimes fatally, when bullets discharged into the air fall back down to the ground. Bullets fired at angles less than vertical are more dangerous as the bullet maintains its angular ballistic trajectory and is far less likely to engage in tumbling motion; it therefore travels at speeds much higher than a bullet in free fall.
[0.633, 0.761, 0.650, 0.741, 0.834] Agent refined response: bullets fired into the air usually falls back with terminal velocities much lower their muzzle velocity when they left the barrel of a firearm, people can be injured, sometimes fatal when bullets discharged into air fall back down to the ground, bullets fired at angles less than the vertical are more dangerous as the bullet maintained its angular ballistic trajectory and are far less likely to engage in the tumbling motion, it therefore travels at speeds higher than a bullet in free fall, a study by the U.S. centers for disease control and Prevention.

So, bullets fired in the air can fall back down to the ground, and the angle of the bullet can affect its speed and trajectory.
[0.076, 0.436, 0.407, 0.436, 0.780] Ori response: bullets fired into the air usually falls back with terminal velocities much lower  than their muzzle velocity when  they leave the barrel of a  firearm.

Prompt: chandra and bhaga river meets at the place
Ground truth: The Chandrabhaga or Chenab (Vedic name Askni), the largest river (in terms of volume of water) is formed after the meeting of two streams namely, Chandra and Bhaga at Tandi, in Lahaul. It flows 122 kilometres (76 mi) and covers an area of 7,500 square kilometres (2,900 sq mi). in Himachal, before entering Kashmir. The Chandra passes through the barren tribal land.

Prompt: when was the national flag of india adopted
Ground truth: The National Flag of India is a horizontal rectangular tricolour of India saffron, white and India green; with the Ashoka Chakra, a 24-spoke wheel, in navy blue at its centre. It was adopted in its present form during a meeting of the Constituent Assembly held on 22 July 1947, and it became the official flag of the Dominion of India on 15 August 1947. The flag was subsequently retained as that of the Republic of India. In India, the term "tricolour" (Hindi: तिरंगा, translit. Tiraṅgā) almost always refers to the Indian national flag. The flag is based on the Swaraj flag, a flag of the Indian National Congress designed by Pingali Venkayya.
[0.000, 0.052, 0.035, 0.052, 0.302] Agent refined response: 15 August 1947.
[0.000, 0.052, 0.035, 0.052, 0.302] Ori response: 15 August 1947.
================================================================================
Prompt: who won the champions league final in 2016
Ground truth: The 2016 UEFA Champions League Final was the final match of the 2015--16 UEFA Champions League, the 61st season of Europe's premier club football tournament organised by UEFA, and the 24th season since it was renamed from the European Champion Clubs' Cup to the UEFA Champions League. It was played at the San Siro stadium in Milan, Italy, on 28 May 2016, between Spanish teams Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid, in a repeat of the 2014 final. It was the second time in the tournament's history that both finalists were from the same city. Real Madrid won 5--3 on a penalty shoot-out after a 1--1 draw at the end of extra time, securing a record-extending 11th title in the competition.
[0.172, 0.411, 0.146, 0.267, 0.589] Agent refined response: Real Madrid won the Champions League final in 2016. The match was played on May 28, 2016, at the Stade de France in Saint-Denis, France, and Real Madrid defeated Atlético Madrid 5-3 in a penalty shootout after the match ended 1-1 (Ramos 15', Carrasco 79') in regular time.
[0.000, 0.131, 0.059, 0.088, 0.457] Ori response: Real Madrid won the Champions League final in 2016.

Prompt: who is often associated with printing the first book using moveable type in germany
Ground truth: Johannes Gutenberg of Mainz, Germany is acknowledged as the first to invent a metal movable-type printing system in Europe, the printing press. Gutenberg was a goldsmith familiar with techniques of cutting punches for making coins from moulds. Between 1436 and 1450 he developed hardware and techniques for casting letters from matrices using a device called the hand mould. Gutenberg's key invention and contribution to movable-type printing in Europe, the hand mould, was the first practical means of making cheap copies of letterpunches in the vast quantities needed to print complete books, making the movable-type printing process a viable enterprise.
[0.002, 0.186, 0.034, 0.136, 0.560] Agent refined response: Johannes Gutenberg is often associated with printing the first Book using moveable type in Germany.
[0.002, 0.186, 0.034, 0.136, 0.560] Ori response: Johannes Gutenberg is often associated with printing the first Book using moveable type in Germany.

Prompt: what was icq as related to instant messaging
Ground truth: ICQ is an instant messaging client that was first developed and popularized by the Israeli company Mirabilis in 1996. The name ICQ derives from the English phrase "I Seek You". Ownership of ICQ passed from Mirabilis to AOL in 1998, and from AOL to Mail.Ru Group in 2010.
[0.167, 0.228, 0.051, 0.190, 0.512] Agent refined response: ICQ is an instant messaging platform that allows users to send and receive messages, including private messages, through its network. Similar to other instant messaging platforms like Skype, YIM, and AIM, ICQ has raised privacy and copyright concerns.

When a user accepts the ICQ privacy policy (2011), they give all the copyright in the posted messages to ICQ Inc. This implies that ICQ Inc. may publish, distribute, or use any messages sent through the system, even if they were meant to be private. Therefore, users should be aware that any information they publish in a public area may be accessible to ICQ or third parties and used by ICQ.
[0.190, 0.255, 0.077, 0.204, 0.505] Ori response: ICQ is an instant messaging client that allows users to communicate with other users in real-time. Similar concerns apply to other instant messengers such as Skype, YIM, and AIM, which also raise privacy and copyright concerns. When a user accepts the ICQ privacy policy (2011), they give all the copyright in the posted Information to ICQ Inc. This implies that ICQ Inc. may publish, distribute, or use any messages sent through the system that were meant to be private. Therefore, users should be aware that any information they may have published in a public area may be accessible to ICQ or third parties and used by ICQ.

Prompt: what was the alliance between great britian russia and france known as
Ground truth: The Triple Entente (from French entente (ɑ̃tɑ̃t) "friendship, understanding, agreement") refers to the understanding linking the Russian Empire, the French Third Republic, and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland after the signing of the Anglo-Russian Entente on 31 August 1907. The understanding between the three powers, supplemented by agreements with Japan and Portugal, was a powerful counterweight to the Triple Alliance of Germany, Austria-Hungary, and Italy.
[0.013, 0.209, 0.024, 0.163, 0.603] Agent refined response: the alliance between Great Britain, Russia, and France was known as the Franco-Russian Alliance.
[0.013, 0.209, 0.024, 0.163, 0.603] Ori response: the alliance between Great Britain, Russia, and France was known as the Franco-Russian Alliance.

The band recorded two albums, the first in 1988 and the second in 1990, though Orbison died before the second was recorded.

================================================================================
Prompt: when did the right to buy scheme start
Ground truth: After Margaret Thatcher became Prime Minister in May 1979, the legislation to implement the Right to Buy was passed in the Housing Act 1980. Michael Heseltine, in his role as Secretary of State for the Environment, was in charge of implementing the legislation. Some 6,000,000 people were affected; about one in three actually purchased their housing unit. Heseltine noted that "no single piece of legislation has enabled the transfer of so much capital wealth from the state to the people". He said the right to buy had two main objectives: to give people what they wanted, and to reverse the trend of ever-increasing dominance of the state over the life of the individual.
[0.000, 0.097, 0.049, 0.097, 0.455] Agent refined response: the right to buy scheme started in 1980.
[0.000, 0.097, 0.049, 0.097, 0.455] Ori response: the right to buy scheme started in 1980.
================================================================================
Prompt: who won the battle of stirling bridge 1297
Ground truth: The Battle of Stirling Bridge was a battle of the First War of Scottish Independence. On 11 September 1297, the forces of Andrew Moray and William Wallace defeated the combined English forces of John de Warenne, 6th Earl of Surrey, and Hugh de Cressingham near Stirling, on the River Forth.
[0.358, 0.345, 0.130, 0.236, 0.537] Agent refined response: the Scots won the Battle of Stirling Bridge in 1297. The passage states that the battle was a "shattering defeat" for the English and that it showed that infantry could be superior to cavalary. The English losses in the battle are recorded as 100 cavalry killed and 5,000 infantry killed, while the Scottish casualties, including Andrew Moray, are unrecorded.
[0.012, 0.233, 0.138, 0.200, 0.565] Ori response: the Scots won the Battle of Stirling Bridge in 1297.
