Prompt: the elements in each period have the same number of
Ground truth: A period in the periodic table is one of the horizontal rows, all of those elements have the same number of electron shells. Going across a period, each element has one more proton and is less metallic than its predecessor. Arranged this way, groups of elements in the same column have similar chemical and physical properties, reflecting the periodic law. For example, the alkali metals lie in the first column (group 1) and share similar properties, such as high reactivity and the tendency to lose one electron to arrive at a noble-gas electronic configuration. As of 2016 a total of 118 elements have been discovered and confirmed.
[0.226, 0.305, 0.109, 0.190, 0.561] Agent refined response: 

* In each period, the elements have the same number of valence electrons. * The elements in each period have the same electron configuration. * The number of periods in the periodic table is equal to the number of valence electrons in the outermost energy level of an atom. * The valence electrons in the outermost level are responsible for the chemical properties of an element. * The number of valence electrons in the periodic table is given by the number of the period. * The number of valence electron shells in the periodic table is equal to 8. * The number of valence shells in the periodic table is the number of periods in the table. * The valence shells in the periodic are the outermost energy levels of an atom. * The valance shells in the periodic table are the same for all elements in the same period. * The valence shells are responsible for the chemical properties of elements. * The valence shells of an element determine the number of bonds that an element can form. * The valence shells also determine the chemical reactivity of an element. * The valence shells can be visualized as a series of concentric shells surrounding the nucleus of an atom. * The valense shells are the outermost energy levels of the
[0.308, 0.335, 0.127, 0.184, 0.556] Ori response: 

1. The general structure of the periodic table in each period has the same number of elements.
2. Of the three heaviest elements with biologic roles, two (molybdenum and iodine) are in this period.
3. Tungsten, in period 6 is heavier, along with several early lanthanides.
4. Period 5 includes technetium, the heaviest exclusively radioactive element.
5. Group 3 (Lanthanides) in period 5 has 15 elements.
6. The atomic number of each element in each period is listed.
7. The elements in each period have the same amount of protons in their atomic nuclei.
8. The elements in each period have different number of neutrons in their atomic nuclei.
9. The number of periods in the periodic table is 18.
10. The number of groups in the periodic table is 10.

Prompt: when did new york stop using the electric chair
Ground truth: Capital punishment is not in force in the State of New York. The last execution took place in 1963, when Eddie Mays was electrocuted at Sing Sing Prison. The state was the first to adopt the electric chair as a method of execution, which replaced hanging. Following the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling declaring existing capital punishment statutes unconstitutional in Furman v. Georgia (1972), New York was without a death penalty until 1995, when then-Governor George Pataki signed a new statute into law, which provided for execution by lethal injection.
[0.000, 0.157, 0.060, 0.157, 0.496] Agent refined response: New York State stopped using the electric chair in 1972.
[0.000, 0.139, 0.061, 0.139, 0.463] Ori response: New York stopped using the electric chair in 1972.

Prompt: when does the heart develop and begin pumping blood
Ground truth: Heart development refers to the prenatal development of the human heart. This begins with the formation of two endocardial tubes which merge to form the tubular heart, also called the primitive heart tube, that loops and septates into the four chambers and paired arterial trunks that form the adult heart. The heart is the first functional organ in vertebrate embryos, and in the human, beats spontaneously by week 4 of development.
[0.360, 0.407, 0.071, 0.291, 0.606] Agent refined response: 

The heart begins to develop in the embryo at around  day 21 or day 22. The heart starts to beat and pump blood around this time. The two tubes, or endocardial tubes, begin to form in the cardiogeneous region of the embryo. As these tubes form, a lumen (or hole) develops in the center of each tube. This lumen will eventually become the heart's four chambers. The tubes then start to fold and twist, eventually forming the heart's walls and chambers. The heart begins to pump blood around the same time that the tubes begin to fold and twist.
[0.528, 0.616, 0.282, 0.453, 0.748] Ori response: 

The heart begins to develop in the embryo as early as week 21 of gestation, when the endocardial tubes form. These tubes eventually fuse to form the tubular heart, which loops and septates into the four heart chambers and paired artery trunks. This process is called heart development or cardiogenesis.

It is essential to note that the heart is the first functional organ to develop in vertebrate embryos and begins to beat spontaneously in the human embryo around week 21 of gestation. This means that the heart starts pumping blood even before the embryo has developed any other organs or systems.

Ground truth: The 2018 FIFA World Cup will be the 21st FIFA World Cup, a quadrennial international football tournament contested by the men's national teams of the member associations of FIFA. It is scheduled to take place in Russia from 14 June to 15 July 2018, after the country was awarded the hosting rights on 2 December 2010. This will be the first World Cup held in Europe since the 2006 tournament in Germany; all but one of the stadium venues are in European Russia, west of the Ural Mountains, to keep travel time manageable.

Prompt: what was the religion in the virginia colony
Ground truth: In the 1740s, the established Anglican church had about 70 parish priests around the colony. There was no bishop, and indeed, there was fierce political opposition to having a bishop in the colony. The Anglican priests were supervised directly by the Bishop of London. Each county court gave tax money to the local vestry, composed of prominent laymen. The vestry provided the priest a glebe of 200 or 300 acres (1.2 km), a house, and perhaps some livestock. The vestry paid him an annual salary of 16,000 pounds-of-tobacco, plus 20 shillings for every wedding and funeral. While not poor, the priests lived modestly and their opportunities for improvement were slim.
[0.267, 0.351, 0.083, 0.206, 0.519] Agent refined response: 

The religion in the Virginia colony was predominantly Anglican, with the Church of England being the established church. However, there was also a significant number of Puritans who immigrated to the colony and established their own congregations. After the English Civil War and the Restoration of the monarchy in 1660, the Church of England was re-established as the official religion of the colony, and the Anglican Church continued to be the dominant religion in Virginia until the American Revolution.
[0.000, 0.143, 0.032, 0.095, 0.475] Ori response: 

The Church of England was the established religion in the Virginia Colony.

Prompt: when was the biltmore house opened to the public
Ground truth: In an attempt to bolster the estate's financial situation during the Great Depression, Cornelia and her husband opened Biltmore to the public in March 1930 at the request of the City of Asheville, which hoped the attraction would revitalize the area with tourism. Biltmore closed during World War II and in 1942, 62 paintings and 17 sculptures were moved to the estate by train from the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. to protect them in the event of an attack on the United States. The Music Room on the first floor was never finished, so it was used for storage until 1944, when the possibility of an attack became more remote. Among the works stored were the Gilbert Stuart portrait of George Washington and works by Rembrandt, Raphael, and Anthony van Dyck. David Finley, the gallery director, was a friend of Edith Vanderbilt and had stayed at the estate.
[0.000, 0.110, 0.062, 0.086, 0.478] Agent refined response: Biltmore House was opened to the public in March 1930.
[0.000, 0.122, 0.062, 0.098, 0.493] Ori response: 

The Biltmore House was opened to the public in March 1930.

Prompt: who's the original singer of help me make it through the night
Ground truth: "Help Me Make It Through The Night" is a country music ballad written and composed by Kris Kristofferson and released on his 1970 album Kristofferson. It was covered later in 1970 by Sammi Smith, on the album Help Me Make It Through the Night. Smith's recording of the song remains the most commercially successful and most well-known version in the United States. Her recording ranks among the most successful country singles of all time in terms of sales, popularity, and radio airplay. It topped the country singles chart, and was also a crossover hit, reaching number eight on the U.S. pop singles chart. "Help Me Make It Through The Night" also became Smith's signature song.
[0.002, 0.207, 0.135, 0.193, 0.526] Agent refined response: Sammi Smith is the original singer of the song "Help Me Make It Through the Night."

Prompt: when do you get a dd form 214
Ground truth: The DD Form 214, Certificate of Release or Discharge from Active Duty, generally referred to as a "DD 214", is a document of the United States Department of Defense, issued upon a military service member's retirement, separation, or discharge from active duty in the Armed Forces of the United States, e.g., U.S. Air Force, U.S. Army, U.S. Coast Guard, U.S. Marine Corps, or U.S. Navy.
[0.290, 0.368, 0.233, 0.239, 0.609] Agent refined response: 

An individual receives a DD Form 214, "Certificate of Release or Discharge from Active Duty," upon retirement, separation, or discharged from active duty in the Armed Forces of the United States. This document serves as proof of their military service and is used for various purposes, such as:

1. Benefits: DD Form 214 is used to determine eligibility for veterans' benefits, such as healthcare, education, and disability compensation.
2. Employment: Many employers require a DD Form 215 as proof of military service for veterans.
3. Education: DD Form 215 is used to verify military service for educational benefits, such as the GI Bill.
4. Veterans Affairs: DD Form 216 is used to determine eligibility and the amount of disability compensation.
5. Death Benefits: DD Forms 214 and 215 are used to determine eligibility for death benefits, such as survivor benefits and burial benefits.

In summary, an individual will receive a DD Form 216 upon separation or discharge from active duty in the
[0.257, 0.296, 0.167, 0.200, 0.566] Ori response: 

An individual receives a DD Form 214, "Certificate of Release or Discharge from Active Duty," after completing their military service and being discharged or released from active duty. The form serves as proof of military service and is used to determine eligibility for various benefits, such as VA benefits, unemployment benefits, and government employment priority.

The most important copy of the DD Form 214 is the long form copy, which is the standard form needed to obtain these benefits. The long form copy contains detailed information about the individual's military service, including the nature and type of discharge and the re-enlistment code. The re-enlistment code is used to determine whether or no the service member can go back into service.

There are eight original copies of the DD Form 2214, with all but the "short form" copy containing information about the nature and type of discharge. The short form copy does not contain this information.

Prompt: where is wind power used most in the united states
Ground truth: In 2016, Nebraska became the eighteenth state to have installed over 1,000 MW of wind power capacity. Texas, with over 20,000 MW of capacity, had the most installed wind power capacity of any U.S. state at the end of 2016. Texas also had more under construction than any other state currently has installed. The state generating the highest percentage of energy from wind power is Iowa. North Dakota has the most per capita wind generation. The Alta Wind Energy Center in California is the largest wind farm in the United States with a capacity of 1548 MW. GE Energy is the largest domestic wind turbine manufacturer.
[0.300, 0.306, 0.099, 0.186, 0.575] Agent refined response:

1. Texas - 20,321 MW
2. Iowa - 6,917 MW
3. Oklahoma - 6,645 MW
4. Kansas - 6,336 MW
5. Minnesota - 5,965 MW
6. North Dakota - 5,741 MW
7. Nebraska - 1,016 MW

Therefore, Texas is the state where wind power is used most in the United States, followed by Iowa, Oklahoma, Kansas, Minnesota, North Dakota, and Nebraska.

Prompt: who appoints the chair of the federal reserve system
Ground truth: The chair is chosen by the President of the United States from among the members of the Board of Governors; and serves for four-year-terms after appointment. A chair may be appointed for several consecutive terms. William Martin was the longest serving chair, holding the position from 1951 to 1970.
[0.394, 0.618, 0.413, 0.539, 0.748] Agent refined response: the Chair of the Federal Reserve System is appointed by the President of the United States from among the members of the Board of Governors. The Chair serves for a four-year term after appointment and may be appointed for several consecutive terms, as seen in the case of William Martin, who served as the longest-serving Chair from 1951 to1970. The current Chairman of the Federal Reserve System is Jerome Powell, who was sworn in On February 5, 2016, and was nominated to the position by President Donald Trump on November 2, 2016, later confirmed by the United States Senate.
[0.275, 0.553, 0.432, 0.500, 0.699] Ori response: The Chair of the Federal Reserve System is appointed by the President of the United States from among the members of the Board of Governors.

Prompt: where is arachidonic acid found in the body
Ground truth: Arachidonic acid is a polyunsaturated fatty acid present in the phospholipids (especially phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylcholine, and phosphatidylinositides) of membranes of the body's cells, and is abundant in the brain, muscles, and liver. Skeletal muscle is an especially active site of arachidonic acid retention, accounting for roughly 10-20% of the phospholipid fatty acid content on average.
[0.241, 0.308, 0.083, 0.195, 0.607] Agent refined response: 

Arachidonic acid is found in the body in several sources, including:

1. Phospholipids: Arachidonic acid is found primarily in phospholipids, which are molecules composed of a glycerol backbone esterified with phosphate groups and a fatty acid chain. These molecules are present in cell membranes throughout the body.
2. Eicosanoid synthesis: Arachidonic acid can be generated through the action of enzymes involved in eicosanoid synthesis, such as phospholipase A2 (PLA2) and diacylglycerol lipases.
3. Group IVA cytosolic phosphatase (CPLA): Arachidonic acid generated for signal transduction purposes is derived from the action of group IVA cytosolic PLA2 (CPLA), which is found in the cytosol of various cells throughout the body.
4. Inflammatory arachidonic acids: Arachidonic acid can also be found in inflammatory cells, such as neutrophils, macrophages, and T cells, where it plays a role in the production of inflammatory e
[0.233, 0.263, 0.085, 0.221, 0.633] Ori response: 

Arachidonic acid is found in the body primarily in the brain, platelets, and adipose tissue. The majority of arachidonic acid in the body is found in the brain, where it plays a crucial role in the synthesis of eicosanoids, which are lipid mediators involved in various physiological processes, including pain modulation, inflammation, and immune response.

Arachidonic acid can also be found in platelets, where it is involved in platelet activation and aggregation. Platelet-derived arachidonic acid has been implicated in the development of thrombosis and cardiovascular disease.

In adipose tissue, arachidonic acid is involved in the regulation of lipolysis and glucose metabolism.

Arachidonic Acid Synthesis and Metabolism in the Body

Arachidonic acid synthesis in the body occurs through the action of enzymes such as phospholipase A2 (PLA2), diacylglycerol lipases, and cytosolic phosphoinositide-specific phosphol

Prompt: what inspired huxley to write brave new world
Ground truth: Huxley said that Brave New World was inspired by the utopian novels of H.G. Wells, including A Modern Utopia (1905) and Men Like Gods (1923). Wells's hopeful vision of the future's possibilities gave Huxley the idea to begin writing a parody of the novel, which became Brave New World. He wrote in a letter to Mrs. Arthur Goldsmith, an American acquaintance, that he had "been having a little fun pulling the leg of H.G. Wells," but then he "got caught up in the excitement of (his) own ideas." Unlike the most popular optimist utopian novels of the time, Huxley sought to provide a frightening vision of the future. Huxley referred to Brave New World as a "negative utopia", somewhat influenced by Wells's own The Sleeper Awakes (dealing with subjects like corporate tyranny and behavioural conditioning) and the works of D.H. Lawrence.
[0.462, 0.420, 0.158, 0.190, 0.614] Agent refined response: 

Huxley was inspired to write Brave New World by several sources, including:

1. H.G. Wells's own utopian novel, The Sleeper Awakes (1910), which deals with themes of corporate tyranny and behavioral conditioning.
2. The works of D.H. Lawrence, whose novels often explored themes of social control and the manipulation of human behavior.
3. George Orwell's belief that Brave New World must have been partly derived from the Soviet Union's political and social climate at the time.
4. Yevgeny Zamyatin's novel We (1924), which explores a dystopian future society where individuality is suppressed and conformity is enforced.
5. J.B. Priestley's essay "The World of the Future" (1940), which predicted a future society where technology and mass production would lead to a loss of individuality and creativity.
6. J.B.S. Haldane's essay "Daedalus" (1923), which explores the idea of a future society where genetic engineering and eugenics would be used
[0.456, 0.475, 0.229, 0.262, 0.646] Ori response: 

Huxley was inspired to write Brave New World by several sources, including:

1. H.G. Wells's The Sleeper Awakes: Huxley was influenced by Wells's novel, which deals with themes of corporate tyranny and behavioral conditioning.
2. D.H. Lawrence's works: Huxley was also influenced by the works of D.H. Lawrence, particularly his novel "The Man Who Died" which explores themes of conformity and rebellion.
3. Yevgeny Zamytin's novel We: George Orwell believed that Brave New World must have been partly derived from Zamytin's novel, which explores a dystopian future society where people are genetically engineered and conditioned to be happy with their predetermined roles in society.

These works served as inspiration for Huxley to create a frightening vision of the future, which he referred to as a "negative utopia."

Prompt: who was the first chief minister of west bengal
Ground truth: Since 1947, there have been eight Chief Ministers of West Bengal. The first was Prafulla Chandra Ghosh of the Indian National Congress, who was succeeded by his party-mates Dr Bidhan Chandra Roy and Prafulla Chandra Sen. A decade of instability followed, marred by fractious coalition governments and frequent impositions of President's rule. The instability ended with 1977 election victory of the Communist Party of India (Marxist) (CPM). Headed by Jyoti Basu, the CPM-led Left Front government was in office for over 23 years (1977--2000). Left rule in West Bengal continued for another 10 years under Buddhadeb Bhattacharya, before its defeat in the 2011 election by the Trinamool Congress. Appointed on 20 May 2011, Trinamool leader Mamata Banerjee is the current incumbent, the state's first woman chief minister.
[0.000, 0.154, 0.085, 0.112, 0.552] Agent refined response: Prafulla Chandra Ghosh was the first Chief Minister of West Bengal.
[0.000, 0.154, 0.085, 0.112, 0.552] Ori response: Prafulla Chandra Ghosh was the first Chief Minister of West Bengal.

Prompt: who is recognized as the founder of islam
Ground truth: According to tradition, the Islamic prophet Muhammad was born in Mecca around the year 570. His family belonged to the Quraysh. When he was about forty years old, he began receiving what Muslims consider to be divine revelations delivered through the angel Gabriel, which would later form the Quran, enjoining him to proclaim a strict monotheistic faith, warn his compatriots of the impending Judgement Day, and castigate social injustices of his city. Muhammad's message won over a handful of followers and was met with increasing opposition from notables of Mecca. In 618, after he lost protection with the death of his influential uncle Abu Talib, Muhammad took flight to the city of Yathrib (subsequently called Medina) where he was joined by his followers. Later generations would count this event, known as the hijra, as the start of the Islamic era.
[0.000, 0.054, 0.014, 0.054, 0.481] Agent refined response: Muhammad is recognized as the founder of Islam.
[0.000, 0.054, 0.014, 0.054, 0.481] Ori response: Muhammad is recognized as the founder of Islam.

Prompt: what is the maximum data rate for the 802.11a standard select one
Ground truth: The 802.11 a standard uses the same data link layer protocol and frame format as the original standard, but an OFDM based air interface (physical layer). It operates in the 5 GHz band with a maximum net data rate of 54 Mbit/s, plus error correction code, which yields realistic net achievable throughput in the mid-20 Mbit/s.
[0.218, 0.323, 0.088, 0.215, 0.627] Agent refined response: 802.11 a standard provides protocols that allow transmission and receipt of data at rates of 1 to 54 Mbps. Therefore, the maximum data rate for the 111 a standard is 54 Mbps.

Prompt: two main types of research methods used in psychology
Ground truth: Correlational research Descriptive research Experimental research
[0.029, 0.061, 0.031, 0.061, 0.427] Agent refined response: psychology has two main types of research methods used:

1. Quantitative Research Methods: These methods involve the use of numerical data and statistical analysis to test hypotheses and answer research questions. Examples of quantitative research methods include:

a. Correlational Research: This method involves examining the relationship between two or more variables, often to identify patterns or associations between them.

b. Descriptive Research: This method involves describing a particular population or phenomenon, often using statistical techniques to summarize and analyze the data.

c. Experimental Research: This method involves manipulating one or more independent variables and measuring their effect on a dependent variable, often using random assignment of participants to treatment or control groups.

d. Experimental Psychology: This method involves using experimental designs to study the psychological processes underlying behavior and mental processes.

e. Field Experiment: This method involves conducting research in a real-world setting, often using a naturalistic or controlled design.

f. Interview: This method involves collecting data through face-to-face conversations with participants, which can be structured or unstructired.

g. Meta-Analysis: This method involves combining data from multiple studies to draw conclusions about a particular research question
[0.023, 0.054, 0.000, 0.054, 0.432] Ori response: psychology research methods can be broadly categorized into two main types:

1. Quantitative Research Methods: These methods are based on numerical data and statistical analysis. They are used to measure and analyze psychological phenomena, and are often used in laboratory experiments. Examples of quantitative research methods include:
* Surveys
* Experiments
* Observational studies
* Correlational studies
* Factor analysis
* Regression analysis
2. Qualitative Research Methods: These methods involve the study of non-numerical data, such as text, images, and observations. They are used to gain a deeper understanding of psychological phenomena, and are particularly useful in exploring new areas of research. Examples of qualitative research methods include:
* Case studies
* Content analysis
* Discourse analysis
* Grounded theory
* Interviews
* Observational studies
* Phenomenology
* Text analysis

It is important to note that many research methods can fall into both categories, and may involve a combination of both qualitative and quantitative approaches.

Prompt: what do the 3 dots mean in math
Ground truth: In logical argument and mathematical proof, the therefore sign (∴) is generally used before a logical consequence, such as the conclusion of a syllogism. The symbol consists of three dots placed in an upright triangle and is read therefore. It is encoded at U + 2234 ∴ therefore (HTML & # 8756; &there4;). For common use in Microsoft Office hold the ALT key and type "8756". While it is not generally used in formal writing, it is used in mathematics and shorthand. It is complementary to U + 2235 ∵ because (HTML & # 8757;).
[0.233, 0.310, 0.067, 0.170, 0.555] Agent refined response: 3 dots in a triangle shape were used by authors in the 18th century to signify "therefore." However, there wasn't much consistency in how the triangle was oriented.

In the 19th century, the three-dot notation for "therefore" became more common, but it remained rare in continental Europe. However, it remains popular in the British Isles.

In mathematics, the three dots are commonly used to indicate a conclusion or a logical implication. For example, in a syllogism, the three dots can be used to represent the conclusion that follows from the premises.

Here's an example of how the three dots can be used in a mathematical argument:

Premise 1: All cats are animals.
Premise 2: All dogs are animals.
Conclusion: Therefore, all cats are dogs.

In this example, the three dots represent the conclusion that follows from the two premises.

It's worth noting that the use of the three dots in mathematical notation is not universal and can vary depending on the context and the individual author or mathematician. However, it is a common convention in many fields of mathematics, including logic,
[0.312, 0.324, 0.040, 0.157, 0.545] Ori response: 3 dots in a triangle shape were used by authors in the 18th century to signify "therefore." However, there wasn't much consistency in how the triangle was oriented.

In the 19th century, the three-dot notation for "therefore" became more common, but it remained rare in continental Europe. However, it remains popular in the British Isles.

In mathematics, the three dots are commonly used to indicate an implied premise or conclusion in a syllogism. For example:

All gods are immortal.
Zeus is a god.
Zeus is immortal.

In this case, the three dots are used to imply the conclusion that Zeus is immortal, based on the premises that all gods are immortal and Zeus is a god.

Prompt: first jnanpith award was an autor of which language
Ground truth: G. Sankara Kurup, (3 June 1901, Nayathode, Kingdom of Cochin (now in Ernakulam district, Kerala, India)--2 February 1978, Vappalassery, Angamaly, Ernakulam district, Kerala), better known as Mahakavi G (The Great Poet G), was the first winner of the Jnanpith Award, India's highest literary award. He won the prize in 1965 for his collection of poems in Malayalam Odakkuzhal (The Bamboo Flute, 1950). With part of the prize money he established the literary award Odakkuzhal in 1968. He was also the recipient of the Soviet Land Nehru Award, in 1967, and the Padma Bhushan in 1968. His poetry collection Viswadarshanam won the Kerala Sahitya Akademi Award in 1961 and Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award in 1963.
[0.000, 0.081, 0.017, 0.065, 0.499] Agent refined response: 1st Jnanpith Award was for Malayalam literature.
[0.078, 0.397, 0.322, 0.371, 0.691] Ori response: Kumaran Asan was the first recipient of the Jnanpith Award, which is India's highest literary award. He won the prize in 1950 for his collection of poems in Malayalam, titled "Odakkuzhal" (The Bamboo Flute).

Prompt: how many cracker barrels in the united states
Ground truth: The number of combined restaurants and stores owned by Cracker Barrel increased between 1997 and 2000, to more than 420 locations. In 2000 and 2001, the company addressed staffing and infrastructure issues related to this rapid growth by implementing a more rigorous recruitment strategy and introducing new technology, including an order-placement system. From the late 1990s to the mid-2000s, the company focused on opening new locations in residential areas to attract local residents and workers as customers. It updated its marketing in 2006 to encourage new customers, changing the design of its highway billboard advertisements to include images of menu items. Previously the signs had featured only the company's logo. By 2011, Cracker Barrel had opened more than 600 restaurants in 42 states. On January 17, 2012, company founder Dan Evins died of bladder cancer.

Prompt: who breaks a tie in the us senate
Ground truth: The Vice President of the United States is the ex officio President of the Senate, as provided in Article I, Section 3, Clause 4, of the United States Constitution, but may only vote in order to break a tie. According to the U.S. Senate, as of February 28, 2018, a tie-breaking vote had been cast 264 times by 36 vice presidents.
[0.412, 0.551, 0.307, 0.427, 0.711] Agent refined response: when there is a tie in the US Senate, the Vice President of the United States (currently Kamala Harris) has the power to break the tie through a vote. This power is granted to the Vice President under Article I, Section 3 of the United States Constitution, which states that the Vice President shall "preside over the Senate, but shall have no vote, unless they be equally divided."

In practice, this means that the Vice President may only vote to break a tie, and their vote is decisive in determining the outcome of the vote. As of February  28, 2023, there have been 264 tie-breaking votes cast by Vice Presidents in the US Senate.
[0.467, 0.521, 0.271, 0.380, 0.669] Ori response: when there is a tie in the US Senate, the Vice President of the United States steps in to break the tie. This is outlined in Article I, Section 3 of the United States Constitution, which states that the Vice President shall "preside over the Senate, but shall not vote, unless they be equally divided." This means that in the event of a tie vote, the Vice President is the deciding vote and can break the tie by voting.

[0.195, 0.210, 0.088, 0.136, 0.441] Agent refined response: 3.1 Coalbed Methane:

"Coalbed methane is a type of natural gas found in coal deposits. In the United States, coalbed methane is found in several regions, including the Powder River Basin in Wyoming, Montana, and North Dakota, the San Juan Basin in New Mexico and Colorado, and the Appalachian Basin in Pennsylvania, West Virginia, and Maryland."

Therefore, coalbed methane is one of the regions in the US where natural gas is found.
[0.111, 0.155, 0.021, 0.104, 0.421] Ori response: the United States has significant natural gas resources, with the country being the world's leading producer of Natural Gas Liquids (NGLs) since 2010. Natural gas is found in various geological formations across the United States, including:

1. Coalbed Methane: This is found in coal deposits, particularly in the western states such as Wyoming, Montana, and Colorado.
2. Shale Gas: The United States has the largest shale gas reserves in the world, with major basins located in Texas, Pennsylvania, North Dakota, and Ohio.

Other geological formations where natural gas is found in the United States include tight gas sandstones, gas sands, and salt domes.

Prompt: where does us highway 1 start and end
Ground truth: U.S. Route 1 (US 1) is a major north--south U.S. Highway that serves the East Coast of the United States. It runs 2,369 miles (3,813 km), from Fort Kent, Maine, at the Canada--US border, south to Key West, Florida, making it the longest north--south road in the United States. US 1 is generally paralleled by Interstate 95 (I-95), though the former is significantly farther west (inland) between Jacksonville, Florida, and Petersburg, Virginia. The highway connects most of the major cities of the East Coast--including Miami, Jacksonville, Richmond, Washington, D.C., Baltimore, Philadelphia, New York City and Boston, passing from the Southeastern United States to New England.

[0.146, 0.203, 0.060, 0.153, 0.551] Agent refined response: NFL training camp for players typically lasts for several weeks, with the exact duration varying from team to team. Here are some specific details regarding the length of NFL training camp:

1. Organized Team Activities (OTAs): These are the only practices held between the end of the previous season (usually in late February or early March) and the start of training camp (which typically begins in late April or early May). OTAs last for about 4-6 weeks.
2. Training Camp: The official training camp for NFL teams typically begins in late April or early July and lasts for 4-6 weeks. During this time, teams hold daily practices, meetings, and drills to prepare for the upcoming season.
3. Preseason Games: After the conclusion of training camp, NFL teams play a series of preseason games, which last for 4-6 weeks. These games are used to evaluate the performance of players and to fine-tune the team's roster before the regular season begins.

In summary, the entire NFL training camp and preseason schedule can last anywhere from 8-10 weeks, depending on the team and the year.

It was played at the San Siro stadium in Milan, Italy, on 28 May 2016, between Spanish teams Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid, in a repeat of the 2014 final. It was the second time in the tournament's history that both finalists were from the same city. Real Madrid won 5--3 on a penalty shoot-out after a 1--1 draw at the end of extra time, securing a record-extending 11th title in the competition.

Prompt: when did beryl markham fly across the atlantic
Ground truth: When Markham decided to take on the Atlantic crossing, no female pilot had yet flown non-stop from Europe to New York, and no woman had made the westward flight solo, though several had died trying. Markham hoped to claim both records. On 4 September 1936, she took off from Abingdon, England. After a 20-hour flight, her Vega Gull, The Messenger, suffered fuel starvation due to icing of the fuel tank vents, and she crash-landed at Baleine Cove on Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia, Canada. She became the first person to make it from England to North America non-stop from east to west. She was celebrated as an aviation pioneer.
[0.000, 0.141, 0.079, 0.109, 0.520] Agent refined response: Beryl Markham successfully flew across the Atlantic from east to west non-stop in 1930.
[0.000, 0.141, 0.079, 0.109, 0.520] Ori response: Beryl Markham successfully flew across the Atlantic from east to west non-stop in 1930.

Prompt: what does the sun represent on the uruguay flag
Ground truth: The horizontal stripes on the flag represent the nine original departments of Uruguay, based on the U.S flag, where the stripes represent the original 13 colonies. The first flag designed in 1828 had 9 light blue stripes; this number was reduced to 4 in 1830 due to visibility problems from distance. The Sun of May represents the May Revolution of 1810; according to the historian Diego Abad de Santillán, the Sun of May is a figurative sun that represents Inti, the sun god of the Inca religion. It also appears in the Flag of Argentina and the Coat of Arms of Bolivia.
[0.001, 0.188, 0.122, 0.137, 0.590] Agent refined response: the sun represents the Inca god Int'i on the flag of Uruguay.
[0.220, 0.456, 0.245, 0.389, 0.696] Ori response: the sun on the Uruguay flag represents the May Revolution of 1810, which was led by José Gervasio Artigas. The sun is also a symbol of Inti, the sun god of the Inca religion, and appears on the flags of Argentina and Bolivia as well.

Prompt: what does it mean to be on parole
Ground truth: Parole is a temporary release of a prisoner who agrees to certain conditions before the completion of the maximum sentence period, originating from the French parole ("voice, spoken words"). The term became associated during the Middle Ages with the release of prisoners who gave their word.
[0.210, 0.274, 0.072, 0.190, 0.554] Agent refined response: "parole is an option for most prisoners." Parole refers to the early release of a prisoner from prison, under certain conditions and supervision, after serving a portion of their sentence. In Canada, parole is available for prisoners serving sentences of two years or more, and the eligibility and conditions of parole vary depending on the jurisdiction.

When a prisoner is granted parole, they are released from prison but are subject to certain restrictions and supervision. These may include reporting regularly to a parole officer, maintaining employment or attending school, avoiding contact with certain individuals or areas, and abstaining from alcohol or drugs. The purpose of parole is to help the prisoner reintegrate into society and prepare them for life outside of prison.
[0.212, 0.278, 0.040, 0.185, 0.519] Ori response: "parole is an option for most prisoners." This means that after serving a certain portion of their sentence, prisoners may be eligible for parole, which is a type of early release from prison. However, as the knowledge also states, parole is not guaranteed, and the likelihood of being granted parole varies depending on the severity of the crime committed and the length of the sentence. For example, prisoners convicted of first-degree murder may be eligible for paroles after 25 years, but the sentencing judge has the option of making the parole ineligibility period consecutive, which could extend the parole ineligibility beyond that time frame.

Prompt: where does the term dog and pony show come from
Ground truth: The term was originally used in the United States in the late-19th and early-20th centuries to refer to small traveling circuses that toured through small towns and rural areas. The name derives from the common use of performing dogs and ponies as the main attractions of the events. Performances were generally held in open-air arenas, such as race tracks or public spaces in localities that were too small or remote to attract larger, more elaborate performers or performances. The most notorious was "Prof. Gentry's Famous Dog & Pony Show," started when teenager Henry Gentry and his brothers started touring in 1886 with their act, originally entitled "Gentry's Equine and Canine Paradox." It started small, but evolved into a full circus show. Other early dog and pony shows included Morris' Equine and Canine Paradoxes (1883) and Hurlburt's Dog and Pony Show (late 1880s).
[0.301, 0.322, 0.082, 0.211, 0.609] Agent refined response: the term "dog and pony show" is a slang term that originated in the United States. The exact origin of the term is unclear, but it is believed to have emerged in the mid-20th century.

One possible origin of the term is from the world of circuses, where a "dog and pony show" was a type of act that featured a dog and a pony performing tricks together. This type of act was often seen as a novelty or a sideshow, rather than a main event.

Another possible origin of the term is from a 1940s-era song called "The Dog and Pony Show," which was written by Bob Dunn and performed by the Ted Fio Rito Orchestra. The song's lyrics feature a dog and a pony performing various tricks and stunts, and the term "dog and pony" became associated with the song and the idea of a traveling show featuring a dog and a pony.

Overall, the term "dog and poney show" is believed to have originated in the United States in the mid-20th centuary, and it is associated with a type of act that featured a performing dog and pony.
[0.333, 0.332, 0.089, 0.176, 0.576] Ori response: the term "dog and pony show" is a slang term that originated in the United States. It is believed to have been used in the early 20th century, possibly as early as the 1920s or 1930s, although the exact origin is unclear.

The term may have been used to suggest that the show is a hodgepodge or a "mishmash" of different acts, rather than a carefully curated program.

Over time, the term "dog and pony" has been used more broadly to describe any entertainment program or event that is perceived as being unremarkable or lacking in quality. It is often used in a derogatory manner to suggest that something is unimpressive or lacking in substance.

Prompt: the origins of the stations of the cross
Ground truth: The Stations of the Cross or the Way of the Cross, also known as the Way of Sorrows or the Via Crucis, refers to a series of images depicting Jesus Christ on the day of his crucifixion and accompanying prayers. The stations grew out of imitations of Via Dolorosa in Jerusalem which is believed to be the actual path Jesus walked to Mount Calvary. The object of the stations is to help the Christians faithful to make a spiritual pilgrimage through contemplation of the Passion of Christ. It has become one of the most popular devotions and the stations can be found in many Western Christian churches, including Anglican, Lutheran, Methodist, and Roman Catholic ones.
[0.293, 0.357, 0.088, 0.189, 0.526] Agent refined response: 

The origins of the stations of the Cross are unclear. The traditional account attributes them to Franciscan friars who accompanied Pope Francis in the 14th century, but there are other theories.

One theory is that the stations were inspired by the 12th-century pilgrims' guide to Jerusalem, the Itinerarium Burdigalense, which describes a "Via Sacra" or "Holy Way" that pilgrims followed to reach the city. However, there is no direct evidence to link this "Via Sacra" with the 14th-century Franciscan stations.

Another theory suggests that the stations were inspired by the accounts of medieval pilgrims who visited the Holy Land, such as Riccoldo da Monte di Croce and Burchard of Mount Sion, who described a "settled route" or "way" that pilgrims followed to Jerusalem. However, these accounts do not specifically mention the 14 stations that are associated with the Franciscan tradition.

The earliest written record of the stations of the Cross is found in the narrative of an English pilgrim named William Wey, who visited the Holy Land in the mid-15th century. Wey's account includes a description of the
[0.346, 0.427, 0.154, 0.242, 0.595] Ori response: the origins of the stations of the Cross can be traced back to the early Christian communities in Jerusalem and the surrounding areas. The earliest known representation of the stations of the Cross dates back to the 4th century, found in a cave church in Jerusalem.

It is believed that the stations of the Cross were developed as a way to help pilgrims and worshipers reflect on the events of Jesus' Passion and Death, as they made their way through the streets of Jerusalem. The stations were placed along the route that Jesus took from his arrest to his burial, and they were meant to provide a visual and spiritual aid for those following the route.

The fourteen traditional stations of the Cross were codified in the 14th century by the Franciscan friars, who traveled throughout Europe spreading the devotion to the Passion of Christ. The Franciscans developed a standardized set of stations, which were based on earlier traditions and the writings of early Christian fathers such as St. Ambrose and St. Gregory of Nyssa.

Over time, the stations of the Cross have evolved to include additional elements, such as the resurrection of Jesus, which is not part of

[0.097, 0.147, 0.046, 0.090, 0.442] Agent refined response: Thomas Jefferson is widely accepted as the primary author of the Declaration of Independence. However, it is acknowledged that several other authors influenced the language and ideas presented in the document.

In particular, George Mason's draft of the Virginia Declaration of Rights was seen as more influential in shaping the language and ideas of the Declaration of Independence, and its language was echoed more frequently in state constitutions and state bils of rights.

As Pauline Maier notes, while there is no evidence that the Declaration of Independence was a "classic statement of American political principles" in the minds of men at the time of its adoption, it did have significant influence on other countries, particularly the leaders of the French Revolution.

Prompt: where does eye of the round roast come from
Ground truth: A round steak is a beef steak from the "round", the rear leg of the cow. The round is divided into cuts including the eye (of) round, bottom round, and top round, with or without the "round" bone (femur), and may include the knuckle (sirloin tip), depending on how the round is separated from the loin. This is a lean cut and it is moderately tough. Lack of fat and marbling makes round dry out when cooked with dry-heat cooking methods like roasting or grilling. Round steak is commonly prepared with slow moist-heat methods including braising, to tenderize the meat and maintain moisture. The cut is often sliced thin, then dried or smoked at low temperature to make jerky.
[0.190, 0.383, 0.155, 0.262, 0.596] Agent refined response: the eye of the round roast comes from the "eye" cut of the round, which is a cut of beef from the rear leg of the animal, near the hip. The eye of the round roast is a specific cut of beef that comes from this area and is typically a more tender and flavorful cut than other cuts from the round.
[0.014, 0.238, 0.142, 0.154, 0.567] Ori response: the "eye of round roast" comes from the "round" cut of beef, which is located in the rear leg of the cow.

Prompt: where do bullets go when fired in the air
Ground truth: Bullets fired into the air usually fall back with terminal velocities much lower than their muzzle velocity when they leave the barrel of a firearm. Nevertheless, people can be injured, sometimes fatally, when bullets discharged into the air fall back down to the ground. Bullets fired at angles less than vertical are more dangerous as the bullet maintains its angular ballistic trajectory and is far less likely to engage in tumbling motion; it therefore travels at speeds much higher than a bullet in free fall.
[0.715, 0.764, 0.564, 0.739, 0.875] Agent refined response: bullets fired into the air usually falls back with terminal velocities much lower their muzzle velocity when they exit the barrel of a firearm, but people can still be injured or killed when bullets discharged into air fall back down to the ground, sometimes at angles less than vertical, which makes them more dangerous because they maintain their angular ballistic trajectory and are less likely to engage in tumble motion, thus traveling at speeds much higher than a falling bullet.
[0.426, 0.574, 0.398, 0.535, 0.784] Ori response: bullets fired into the air usually falls back with terminal velocities much lower that their muzzle velocity when they exit the barrel of a firearm, which means that they will not fly as fast as they were traveling when they were fired from the gun. This is because air resistance slows them down as they travel through the air.

However, people can still be injured or killed if bullets fired into the air fall back to the ground. This is because the bullet can travel at a high speed even if it is not flying as fast as it was when it was fired from the gun.

It is important to note that bullets fired at angles less than the vertical are more dangerous than those fired at a vertical angle. This is because the bullet maintains its angular ballistics trajectory and is less likely to engage in tumbering motion as it falls back to the ground. As a result, it will travel at speeds much higher than a bulllet in free fall.

Ground truth: ICQ is an instant messaging client that was first developed and popularized by the Israeli company Mirabilis in 1996. The name ICQ derives from the English phrase "I Seek You". Ownership of ICQ passed from Mirabilis to AOL in 1998, and from AOL to Mail.Ru Group in 2010.
[0.276, 0.291, 0.035, 0.171, 0.524] Agent refined response: ICQ (I Seek You) was the first standalone instant messenger and the first online real-time chat service. It was initially released in November 1996 and was freely available for users to download. Users could register an account and be assigned a unique number, similar to a phone number, for others to contact them. Additionally, users could provide handles for others to use instead of their assigned number.

Prompt: who is often associated with printing the first book using moveable type in germany
Ground truth: Johannes Gutenberg of Mainz, Germany is acknowledged as the first to invent a metal movable-type printing system in Europe, the printing press. Gutenberg was a goldsmith familiar with techniques of cutting punches for making coins from moulds. Between 1436 and 1450 he developed hardware and techniques for casting letters from matrices using a device called the hand mould. Gutenberg's key invention and contribution to movable-type printing in Europe, the hand mould, was the first practical means of making cheap copies of letterpunches in the vast quantities needed to print complete books, making the movable-type printing process a viable enterprise.
[0.002, 0.203, 0.034, 0.153, 0.564] Agent refined response: Johannes Gutenberg is often associated with printing the first books using moveable type in Germany.
[0.002, 0.186, 0.034, 0.136, 0.560] Ori response: Johannes Gutenberg is often associated with printing the first  book using moveable type in Germany.

Prompt: when does canada switch to daylight savings time
Ground truth: In regions where daylight saving time is used, it commences on the second Sunday of March, and standard time restarts on the first Sunday in November.
[0.098, 0.155, 0.078, 0.116, 0.482] Agent refined response: Canada synchronizes its daylight saving time (DST) observance with the United States to promote consistent economic and social interaction, and any changes made by the United States are adopted by Canadian provinces and territories at different times.

Here are the dates when each Canadian province and territory adopted the latest changes to DST made by the United States:

* Ontario: October 20, 2015
* Manitoba: October 20, 1987 (when the United States extended DST to the first Sunday in April)
* Quebec: December 5, 2007
* Prince Edward Island: December 6, 2007
New Brunswick: December 23, 2017

So, the answer to your question is that Canada does not have a fixed date for switching to DST, as it varies depending on the province or territory and the changes made by the United States.
[0.086, 0.205, 0.073, 0.144, 0.528] Ori response: Canada observes Daylight Saving Time (DST) in all ten Canadian provinces and three territories. However, there are exceptions within several provinces, including most of Saskatchewan, which observers Central Standard Time year-round, even though the province is in the Mountain zone, effectively putting it on DST year-round.

In Canada, the start and end dates of DST vary by province or territory. Here are the approximate start and end dates of DST in each province or territory:

* British Columbia: Second Sunday in March (11:00 PM) to first Sunday in November (2:00 AM)
* Nunavut: Second Sunday in March (12:00 AM) to first Sunday in November (1:00 AM)
* Ontario: First Sunday in March (2:00 AM) to last Sunday in October (2:00 AM) (except for the portion of the province west of the Manitoba border, which observes Central Standard Time year-round)
* Quebec: Second Sunday in March (1:00 AM) to last Saturday in October (1:00 AM) (except the portion of the province south of

Prompt: when was the national flag of india adopted
Ground truth: The National Flag of India is a horizontal rectangular tricolour of India saffron, white and India green; with the Ashoka Chakra, a 24-spoke wheel, in navy blue at its centre. It was adopted in its present form during a meeting of the Constituent Assembly held on 22 July 1947, and it became the official flag of the Dominion of India on 15 August 1947. The flag was subsequently retained as that of the Republic of India. In India, the term "tricolour" (Hindi: तिरंगा, translit. Tiraṅgā) almost always refers to the Indian national flag. The flag is based on the Swaraj flag, a flag of the Indian National Congress designed by Pingali Venkayya.
[0.000, 0.160, 0.049, 0.128, 0.489] Agent refined response: 15 August 1947 was the day when India adopted its national flag.
[0.000, 0.160, 0.049, 0.112, 0.484] Ori response: 15 August 1947 is the date when India adopted its national flag.

Prompt: when did the right to buy scheme start
Ground truth: After Margaret Thatcher became Prime Minister in May 1979, the legislation to implement the Right to Buy was passed in the Housing Act 1980. Michael Heseltine, in his role as Secretary of State for the Environment, was in charge of implementing the legislation. Some 6,000,000 people were affected; about one in three actually purchased their housing unit. Heseltine noted that "no single piece of legislation has enabled the transfer of so much capital wealth from the state to the people". He said the right to buy had two main objectives: to give people what they wanted, and to reverse the trend of ever-increasing dominance of the state over the life of the individual.
[0.000, 0.094, 0.048, 0.094, 0.455] Agent refined response: 1980 is the year when the Right to Buy scheme started.
[0.000, 0.080, 0.049, 0.080, 0.453] Ori response: 1980 is when the Right to Buy scheme started.

Prompt: what proposition made the insurance commissioner an elected position
Ground truth: As a result of the passage of Proposition 103 in 1988, the elected office of the California Insurance Commissioner was created in 1991. Previously, the position was held by a person appointed by the Governor. The Insurance Commissioner oversees the Department of Insurance. Democrat Dave Jones won the November 2, 2010 election for California Insurance Commissioner.

Prompt: where does the saying keeping up with the jones come from
Ground truth: The phrase originates with the comic strip Keeping Up with the Joneses, created by Arthur R. "Pop" Momand in 1913. The strip ran until 1940 in The New York World and various other newspapers. The strip depicts the social climbing McGinis family, who struggle to "keep up" with their neighbors, the Joneses of the title. The Joneses were unseen characters throughout the strip's run, often spoken of but never shown. The idiom keeping up with the Joneses has remained popular long after the strip's end.
[0.496, 0.648, 0.476, 0.552, 0.799] Agent refined response: the phrase "Keeping up with the Joneses" originates from the comic strip "Keeping Up with the Joneses" created by Arthur R. "Pop" Momand in 1913, which depicted the social climbing McGinis family struggling to keep up with their neighbors, the Joneses. The phrase gained popularity through the strip and has remained a common idiom long after its end.
[0.358, 0.611, 0.527, 0.534, 0.771] Ori response: the phrase "Keeping up with the Joneses" originates from the comic strip "Keeping Up with the Joneses" created by Arthur R. "Pop" Momand in 1913, which depicted the social climbing McGinis family struggling to keep up with their neighbors, the Joneses of the title.

Prompt: what role does the president play in foreign affairs
Ground truth: Subject to the advice and consent role of the U.S. Senate, the President of the United States negotiates treaties with foreign nations, but treaties enter into force if ratified by two-thirds of the Senate. The President is also Commander in Chief of the United States Armed Forces, and as such has broad authority over the armed forces. Both the Secretary of State and ambassadors are appointed by the President, with the advice and consent of the Senate. The United States Secretary of State acts similarly to a foreign minister and under Executive leadership is the primary conductor of state-to-state diplomacy.
[0.484, 0.599, 0.251, 0.294, 0.701] Agent refined response: the president plays a significant role in foreign affairs, with the advice and consent of Congress. The president acts as the primary conductor of state-to-state diplomacy, and has the power to negotiate and ratify treaties. The Constitution grants the president the authority to make treaties, appoint ambassadors, and recognize foreign governments. Additionally, the president has the power to declare war, with the advice and consent of two-thirds of the Senate.

Prompt: where are trigger points located in the body
Ground truth: Myofascial trigger points, also known as trigger points, are described as hyperirritable spots in the fascia surrounding skeletal muscle. They are associated with palpable nodules in taut bands of muscle fibers. They are a topic of ongoing controversy, as there is limited data to inform a scientific understanding of the phenomenon. Accordingly, a formal acceptance of myofascial "knots" as an identifiable source of pain is more common among bodyworkers, physical therapists, chiropractors, and osteopathic practitioners. Nonetheless, the concept of trigger points provides a framework which may be used to help address certain musculoskeletal pain.
[0.321, 0.276, 0.067, 0.166, 0.507] Agent refined response: trigger points are located in various areas of the body, including:



1. Muscles: Trigger points are most commonly found in muscles, particularly in areas where muscles are subjected to repetitive stress or strain. These areas may include the neck, back, shoulders, arms, and legs.

2. Fascia: The fascia, a connective tissue surrounding muscles, should also be treated to elongiate and resolve strain patterns. If muscles are returned to positions where trigger points remain, they will simply reappear.

Please let me know if you have any other questions.
[0.234, 0.271, 0.059, 0.154, 0.522] Ori response: trigger points are located in the muscles of the body. Specifically, they are found in the skeletal muscles, which are the muscles that are attached to the bones and help move the body's joints. Trigger points are areas within these muscles where there is a knot or a band of tension that can cause pain or discomfort. These areas of tension can be caused by a variety of factors, including injury, inflammation, or poor posture.

Some common locations for trigger points in the body include:

* The neck and shoulder muscles, which can cause pain or stiffness in the neck, shoulders, or upper back
* The back muscles, which can cause pain in the lower back, upper back, or sides
* The abdominal muscles, which can cause pain, discomfort, or cramping in the abdomen
* The hip and thigh muscles, which can cause pain of the hip, thigh, or knee
* The leg muscles, which can cause pain down the leg or in the foot.

Prompt: who was the ottoman governor who led egypt in the years following the napoleonic wars
Ground truth: Egypt under the Muhammad Ali dynasty remained nominally an Ottoman province. It was granted the status of an autonomous vassal state or Khedivate in 1867. Isma'il Pasha and Tewfik Pasha governed Egypt as a quasi-independent state under Ottoman suzerainty until the British occupation of 1882. Nevertheless, the Khedivate of Egypt (1867--1914) remained a de jure Ottoman province until 5 November 1914, when it was declared a British protectorate in reaction to the decision of the Young Turks of the Ottoman Empire to join the First World War on the side of the Central Powers.
[0.255, 0.279, 0.025, 0.158, 0.525] Agent refined response: Koca Musa Pasha was the Ottoman governor who led Egypt in the years following the Napoleonic Wars. Specifically, he was appointed as the governor of Egypt in 1630, and he served in that position until 1656. During his tenure, he faced a challenge from the Egyptian aristocracy, who were displeased with his execution of Kits Bey, an officer who was to have led an Egyptian force to Persia.

Prompt: when did equus first appear in fossil record
Ground truth: The first Old World equid fossil was found in the gypsum quarries in Montmartre, Paris, in the 1820s. The tooth was sent to the Paris Conservatory, where it was identified by Georges Cuvier, who identified it as a browsing equine related to the tapir. His sketch of the entire animal matched later skeletons found at the site.
[0.030, 0.135, 0.028, 0.108, 0.465] Agent refined response: Equus first appeared in the fossil record during the late Miocene, around 7-8 million years ago.

Prompt: sending money home to the native country is an example of
Ground truth: A remittance is a transfer of money by a foreign worker to an individual in his or her home country. Money sent home by migrants competes with international aid as one of the largest financial inflows to developing countries. Workers' remittances are a significant part of international capital flows, especially with regard to labour-exporting countries. In 2014, $436 billion went to developing countries, setting a new record. Overall global remittances totaled $582 billion in 2015. Some countries, such as India and China, receive tens of billions of US dollars in remittances each year from their expatriates and diaspora. In 2014, India received an estimated $70 billion and China an estimated $64 billion.
[0.070, 0.336, 0.082, 0.188, 0.603] Agent refined response: sending money home by migrant workers is an example of "remittances." Remittances refer to the money sent home by migrants to their native country, which can be a significant source of foreign exchange for developing countries.
[0.001, 0.172, 0.016, 0.109, 0.543] Ori response: sending money home by migrant workers to their native country is an example of "remittances".

Prompt: ambulatory is a term used in health care to describe
Ground truth: Ambulatory care or outpatient care is medical care provided on an outpatient basis, including diagnosis, observation, consultation, treatment, intervention, and rehabilitation services. This care can include advanced medical technology and procedures even when provided outside of hospitals.
[0.208, 0.300, 0.116, 0.229, 0.652] Agent refined response: ambulatory care refers to health conditions where appropriate ambulatory or outpatient care prevents or reduces the need for inpatient hospital admission. It includes various medical investigations, treatments, and preventive healthcare services that can be provided on an outpatient basis, such as:

1. Minor surgical and medical procedures.
2. Most types of dental services.
3. Dermatology services.
4. Many types of diagnostic procedures (e.g., blood tests, X-rays, endoscopy, and biopsy procedures of superfluous organs).
5. Emergency visits.
6. Rehabilitation visits.
7. Telephone consultations (in some cases).

In summary, ambulatory care refers to medical care that does not require an overnight hospital stay.

Prompt: what is foreign account tax compliance act (fatca)
Ground truth: The Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) is a 2010 United States federal law requiring all non-U.S. (' foreign ') financial institutions (FFIs) to search their records for customers with indicia of ' U.S.-person ' status, such as a U.S. place of birth, and to report the assets and identities of such persons to the U.S. Department of the Treasury. FATCA also requires such persons to self-report their non-U.S. financial assets annually to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) on form 8938, which is in addition to the older and further redundant requirement to self-report them annually to the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) on form 114 (also known as' FBAR '). Like U.S. income tax law, FATCA applies to U.S. residents and also to U.S. citizens and green card holders residing in other countries.
[0.421, 0.629, 0.546, 0.594, 0.813] Agent refined response: Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) is a 2010 United States federal law that requires foreign financial institutions (FFIs) to search their records for customers with ties to the United States, such as a U.S. place of birth, and to provide information about these customers to the U.S. Department of the Treasury. FATCA also requires U.S. taxpayers to self-report their non-U.S. financial assets to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) on Form 8938, which may be in addition to other reporting requirements.
[0.618, 0.795, 0.752, 0.779, 0.895] Ori response: the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) is a 2010 United States federal law that requires all non-U.S. ("foreign") financial institutions (FFIs) to search their records for customers with "indicia of U.S. person status," such as a U.S. place of birth, and to  report the assets and identities of  such persons to the U.S. Department of the Treasury. FATCA also requires such persons to self-report their non-U.S. financial assets annually to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) on Form 8938, which  is in addition to the older Form 114, the FBAR (Foreign Bank Account Report).

Prompt: when did they start vaccinating for whooping cough
Ground truth: Before vaccines, an average of 178,171 cases was reported in the U.S., with peaks reported every two to five years; more than 93% of reported cases occurred in children under 10 years of age. The actual incidence was likely much higher. After vaccinations were introduced in the 1940s, pertussis incidence fell dramatically to approximately 1,000 by 1976. Incidence rates have increased since 1980. In 2015, rates in the United States were 20,762 people.

The Declaration of Independence, written in 1776, is a document that outlines the reasons why the thirteen American colonies sought independence from Great Britain. While it is not a constitutional document, it has had a significant impact on the development of the United States and its legal system.



The phrase "life, liberty, and property" is found in the Declaration of Independence, and it is believed to have been influenced by the ideas of John Locke, an English philosopher who wrote extensively on political philosophy and the natural rights of individuals. Locke argued that individuals have inherent rights to life, liberty, and property, and that governments derive their authority from the consent of the governed.

The Declaration of Independence, written in 1776, is a foundational document of the United States, and it sets forth the principles upon which the country was founded. However, it is not a legally binding document, and it does not provide a comprehensive list of individual rights that are protected by the Constitution.

Prompt: where does the term pop music come from
Ground truth: According to the website of The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, called Grove Music Online, the term "pop music" "originated in Britain in the mid-1950s as a description for rock and roll and the new youth music styles that it influenced". The Oxford Dictionary of Music states that while pop's "earlier meaning meant concerts appealing to a wide audience. since the late 1950s, however, pop has had the special meaning of non-classical mus (ic), usually in the form of songs, performed by such artists as the Beatles, the Rolling Stones, ABBA, etc". Grove Music Online also states that ". in the early 1960s, (the term) ' pop music ' competed terminologically with beat music (in England), while in the USA its coverage overlapped (as it still does) with that of ' rock and roll '".
[0.377, 0.419, 0.133, 0.256, 0.590] Agent refined response: the term "pop music" originated in the early 1950s as a marketing term created by the American music industry to describe the new genre of popular music that was emerging at the time. The term was intended to distinguish this new music from the more traditional, classical-based music that was being played on radio stations and in concert halls. The term "pop music" was seen as more catchy and memorable than other terms that were used to describe this type of music, such as "light music" or "middle-of-the-road music." Over time, the term "pop music" became widely adopted and is now used to describe a wide range of popular music styles, including rock, R&B, hip-hop, and more.
[0.287, 0.357, 0.114, 0.235, 0.589] Ori response: the term "pop music" originated in the early 20th century as a shorthand for popular music, which was used to describe the commercial music that was gaining widespread popularity and acceptance among the masses. Prompt: what is the full scientific name for the e. coli bacteria
Ground truth: Escherichia coli (/ˌɛʃɪˈrɪkiə ˈkoʊlaɪ/; also known as E. coli) is a Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic, rod-shaped, coliform bacterium of the genus Escherichia that is commonly found in the lower intestine of warm-blooded organisms (endotherms). Most E. coli strains are harmless, but some serotypes can cause serious food poisoning in their hosts, and are occasionally responsible for product recalls due to food contamination. The harmless strains are part of the normal flora of the gut, and can benefit their hosts by producing vitamin K, and preventing colonization of the intestine with pathogenic bacteria, having a symbiotic relationship. E. coli is expelled into the environment within fecal matter. The bacterium grows massively in fresh fecal matter under aerobic conditions for 3 days, but its numbers decline slowly afterwards.
[0.002, 0.152, 0.028, 0.097, 0.505] Agent refined response: the full scientific name for the Escherichia coli (E. coli) bacteria is Escherichia coli (KNOW).
[0.000, 0.153, 0.028, 0.097, 0.511] Ori response: the full scientific name for the Escherichia coli (E. coli) bacteria is Escherichia coli.

Prompt: when was the rock and roll hall of fame built in cleveland
Ground truth: The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, located on the shore of Lake Erie in downtown Cleveland, Ohio, recognizes and archives the history of the best-known and most influential artists, producers, engineers, and other notable figures who have had some major influence on the development of rock and roll. The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Foundation was established on April 20, 1983, by Atlantic Records founder and chairman Ahmet Ertegun. In 1986, Cleveland was chosen as the Hall of Fame's permanent home. Since opening in September 1995, the "Rock Hall"--part of the city's redeveloped North Coast Harbor--has hosted more than 10 million visitors and had a cumulative economic impact estimated at more than $1.8 billion.

Prompt: what is the width of a cricket bat
Ground truth: A cricket bat is a specialised piece of equipment used by batsmen in the sport of cricket to hit the ball, typically consisting of a cane handle attached to a flat-fronted willow-wood blade. The length of the bat may be no more than 38 inches (965 mm) and the width no more than 4.25 inches (108 mm). Its use is first mentioned in 1624. Since 1979, a rule change stipulated that bats can only be made from wood.

Prompt: where are the hormones of the anterior pituitary created
Ground truth: The pars distalis, (distal part), comprises the majority of the anterior pituitary and is where the bulk of pituitary hormone production occurs. The pars distalis contains two types of cells including chromophobe cells and chromophil cells. The chromophils can be further divided into acidophils (alpha cells) and basophils (beta cells). These cells all together produce hormones of the anterior pituitary, and release them into the blood stream.
[0.273, 0.297, 0.083, 0.185, 0.536] Agent refined response: the hormones of the anterior pituiary gland are created in the following way:

1. Stress: Stress induces the release of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) and vasopressin from the hypalamus, which activatesthe release of adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH) from the anterior pituitary glan.
2. ACTH: The ACTH acts on the adrenal cortexto produce glucocorticoids, such as cortisol.
3. Glucocorticoids: These glucocorticoids act on the anterior pituitary glans and the hypothalamus withnegative feedback to slow the production of CRH and ACTH.
4. CRH and ACTH: CRH and ACTH are produced in the hypothalamus and released into the hypophyseal portal system.

5. HPA axis: The production and release of CRH and ACTH are regulated by the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, which is a complex system that involves the hypothalamus, pituitary g
[0.248, 0.267, 0.076, 0.225, 0.535] Ori response: the hormones of the anterior  pituitary gland are created through the following process:

1. Stress: Stress induces the release of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) and vasopressin from the  hypothalamus.
2. Activation of the anterior pituitary glands: CRH and vasopressin activate the release of adrenocorticoidotropic hormone (ACTH) from the anterior pituitary  gland.
3. Production of glucocorticoids: The adrenal cortex produces glucocorticoids such  as cortisol in response to ACTH.
4. Negative feedback: The glucocorticoids produced by the adrenal cortex act back on the anterior pituitar gland and the hypothalamuses with negative feedback to slow the production  of CRH.

Therefore, the hormones of the anterior hypophysis are created through a complex interplay between stress, the hypothalamus, the pituitary gland, and the adrenal cortex.

Prompt: how long did it take to build the great pyramid of egypt
Ground truth: Egyptologists believe the pyramid was built as a tomb for the Fourth Dynasty Egyptian pharaoh Khufu (often Hellenized as "Cheops") and was constructed over a 20-year period. Khufu's vizier, Hemiunu (also called Hemon) is believed by some to be the architect of the Great Pyramid. It is thought that, at construction, the Great Pyramid was originally 280 Egyptian Royal cubits tall (146.5 metres (480.6 ft)), but with erosion and absence of its pyramidion, its present height is 138.8 metres (455.4 ft). Each base side was 440 cubits, 230.4 metres (755.9 ft) long. The mass of the pyramid is estimated at 5.9 million tonnes. The volume, including an internal hillock, is roughly 2,500,000 cubic metres (88,000,000 cu ft).
[0.003, 0.143, 0.039, 0.104, 0.462] Agent refined response: 10 to 20 years are estimated to have passed between 2560 BC and 2540 BC during the construction of the Great Pyramid of Giza.
[0.115, 0.271, 0.063, 0.146, 0.520] Ori response: 14 years is the estimated time span for the construction of the Great Pyramid of Giza, with a peak workforce of roughly 30,000 people. This estimate is based on a modern construction management study in association with Egyptologists, and suggests that the pyramid was completed from start-to-finish in approximately 10 years without the use of pulleys or iron tools.

Prompt: why did the colonists have a problem with the tea act of 1773
Ground truth: The Tea Party was the culmination of a resistance movement throughout British America against the Tea Act, which had been passed by the British Parliament in 1773. Colonists objected to the Tea Act because they believed that it violated their rights as Englishmen to "No taxation without representation", that is, to be taxed only by their own elected representatives and not by a British parliament in which they were not represented. In addition, the well-connected East India Company had been granted competitive advantages over colonial tea importers, who resented the move and feared additional infringement on their business. Protesters had successfully prevented the unloading of taxed tea in three other colonies, but in Boston, embattled Royal Governor Thomas Hutchinson refused to allow the tea to be returned to Britain.
[0.357, 0.587, 0.432, 0.498, 0.745] Agent refined response: the colonists objected to the Tea Act of 1773 because they believed it violated their rights as Englishmen to "no taxation without representation," meaning they should be taxed only by their own elect representatives and not by a British parliament in which they were not represented (1). They also resented the competitive advantages granted to the well-connected East India Company, which they feared would further infringe on their business (1).
[0.339, 0.554, 0.340, 0.406, 0.731] Ori response: the colonists objected to the Tea Act of 1773 because they believed it violated their rights as Englishmen to "no taxation without representation," meaning they were only willing to be taxed by their own elected representatives and felt the British Parliament had no authority to tax them without their consent. They also resented the competitive advantages granted to the East India Company, which gave them an unfair advantage over colonial tea importers.

Prompt: where did the beer hall putsch take place
Ground truth: The Beer Hall Putsch, also known as the Munich Putsch, and, in German, as the Hitlerputsch, Hitler-Ludendorff-Putsch, Bürgerbräu-Putsch or mostly Marsch auf die Feldherrnhalle, was a failed coup attempt by the Nazi Party (NSDAP) leader Adolf Hitler--along with Generalquartiermeister Erich Ludendorff and other Kampfbund leaders--to seize power in Munich, Bavaria, during 8--9 November 1923. About two thousand Nazis marched to the centre of Munich, where they confronted the police, which resulted in the death of 16 Nazis and four police officers. Hitler was not wounded during the clash, although he locked his left arm with the right arm of Max Erwin von Scheubner-Richter who, when he was shot and killed, pulled Hitler to the pavement with him. Hitler escaped immediate arrest and was spirited off to safety in the countryside. After two days, Hitler was arrested and charged with treason.
[0.002, 0.154, 0.060, 0.142, 0.491] Agent refined response: the Beer Hall Putsch took place in Munich, Bavaria, Germany. The exact location of the event was Marienplatz in Munich.
[0.004, 0.163, 0.071, 0.128, 0.522] Ori response: the Beer Hall Putsch took place in Munich, Bavaria, Germany. Specifically, it occurred at the Marienplatz in Munich on November 8-9, 1923.
